reviewText: Among the Sleep is a horror game that has a really unique aproach to horror. But will you want to play this through ? In Among the Sleep you dont play as an adult but instead as a two year old child. The game begins and its our birthday and we get a teddy bear as a present. But one night you wake up to find out that the teddy bear and your mom is missing so its up to you to find them. So how is Among the sleep ? Im kinda mixed on this game honestly. The gameplay is smooth and its a blast to play but there are problems that weigh down the experience. First of all the game is just like amnesia. The main charecter is defensless and theres nothing you can do about it so you have to hide to get away from monsters. The game also throws in puzzles you need to solve to get to the end. So now for the pros and cons. Pros: The game looks amazing. Its just amazing to see a nightmare world through a childs eyes. The story has a great set up and the ending is also really good. Atmosphere is outstandng and its one of the best i have ever seen in a horror game. But now for the cons. The game is incredibly short only an hour to beat. Easy puzzles that dont feel like they should be there. Sometimes frustrating stealth segments. Confusing map layouts and sometimes wonky controls. Overall Among the Sleep is an excellent horror game but it has its fare share of problems. I highly suggest you get this game on a sale and not full priced and dont go in expecting a masterpiece and you should be all good. I give Among the Sleep a 7/10\n\nFor more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
***After latest patch***
I've always been fascinated by the game concept, to be introduced to the world through a child's eyes. Where everything and anything is possible. A world so full of life and colors, danger and adventure, fear and magic. Nothing your plain adult life could bring you close to. A world where you can be the hero of your bedtime story. You begin your adventure at night, the time when we rest after a long day, time where nothing mostly ever happens. But not for a 2 years old!

Among the Sleep, introduces you to a terrifying experience, which is completely insane and traumatizing on a basic human level. Takes place on a stormy late night, your mother is missing and you're a helpless little infant who sets off on a quest to rescue her. While he faces his fears of being lost in the dark, monsters lurking in the closets and every dark corner, worlds shifting, objects stretching which gives the illusion of hellish presence in the most clever ways I have ever seen, that you begin to imagine things and jump at the slightest noise. A psychological masterpiece.

Many recent horror games, such as Outlast, Amnesia, DreadOut and more, have been aiming to achieve making the player feel helpess in the face of danger or supernatural exsitence, by stripping away any means of fighting back. Which is probably the scariest feeling of all. But I can't imagine what could be more helpless than a little toddler, who can't yet talk and can barely walk, so you're basically forced to cope with your surrounding.

A big thank you to the Devs for releasing an update with new achievements. Being an achievement hunter, I had to replay the game, and it was even more rewarding than my first playthrough. It opened my eyes and made me realize what a special little game it was. It also added a Slenderman feeling into it, only a toddler version.
The game runs perfectly smooth, haven't encountered a single problem, still has its amazing visuals and physics and I noticed a greater update in the ambiance and sounds, which creates a much better horror atmposphere.

I strongly believe this game deserves a lot more credit, as it leaves a strong impact on you that a lot of big titles can't do. With its provoking story and innovation to the horror genre, I urge you to try it.
Such rich gem is very rare to find!

reviewText:
I'm so ashamed of myself. I can't believe I had this game in my library for close to a year and ignored it for all that time. I was so in the mood for shooters or some puzzle games that everything else was pushed to the side. But one day I was in the mood for something where I could traverse at ankle height and defecate myself involuntarily, and, boy, am I glad I found this little gem to scratch that particular itch.

This is going to be a slightly awkward one to write about because half the fun of the game is not knowing exactly what it is then discovering it as you go along, most of which is best left unsaid. What I can say about it, though, is it's predominantly a psychological horror played through the eyes of a small boy on his second birthday as you crawl your way through stages related to his life in search of his missing mother along with the aid of his tiny teddy bear friend, occasionally toddling around on your hind legs like a wee little Rory Calhoun. It sounds like it could be gimmicky or a million miles away from anything that would typically be relevant to your interests, but believe me, there's so much more beneath that unassuming surface.

By doing something as small as lowering the player's view to ground level, there's instantly a very fresh and unique feel to the game. Add to that the fact you're playing as a baby trying to navigate an adult world where a simple everyday object now becomes a sizable hurdle, and you've got something even more captivating. But then throw it all inside a horror game and you've got the perfect recipe for something really special. All of that could have been enough by itself, but they took it even further and went to great lengths conveying the world as filtered through the barely developed mind of an infant.

It's incredibly easy to take for granted, and I never really thought about it myself 'til now, but this game really makes you think about and appreciate what it must be like to inhabit the world as someone who's practically a stranger to it, and how it does that is a stroke of genius, as everything that's unfamiliar becomes alien and terrifying. A crash of lightning feels like an earthquake, or a household appliance could be an evil monster waiting to get us should we disturb it, even words on labels or books are gibberish symbols since we don't understand how to read them. You can even hug your teddy bear at times to make you feel safe"
date: "safe" in this case being to illuminate the path immediately ahead of you. The way it plays with your perceptions and interpretations of everything around you and feeds you back distortions of the child's own fragmented memories is a master stroke of design and execution that succeeds from the start right through to the increasingly dark end.\n\nThat end won't be too far for most people

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a game of perspective and confusion, seen through the eyes of a toddler in a world vastly larger and more terrifying.

Its appeal is largely wrapped in this unusual viewpoint, but it's so novel and well executed that it's a strong enough hook to pivot a game around that if shown any other way would likely fall entirely flat. Seeing the dark and often surreal world around you from barely a few feet off the ground, your awkward steps making a quick escape unlikely as you stumble and fall in an attempt to run from the nightmares that haunt you, is frightening and enthralling. The vulnerability felt through playing as such a small character is immense, and had me scurrying under chairs and attempting to pry open cabinets as my only defense was to hide where the monsters pursuing me wouldn't think to look.

It's hard to deny that beyond making your way from each twisted environment to the next there's very little interactivity to be found in Among the Sleep, but in most cases this works in the games favor and makes sense given a toddler's limited motor skills. There aren't involved puzzles or elaborate mechanics to deal with, it's simply you and your teddy bear trying to find your mother before the horrors around you find you first, and this simplicity allowed me to fully embody my role in this world that was intentionally beyond my comprehension. Much of the narrative is told nonverbally through the environment, with themes of alcoholism, domestic abuse, and child abandonment dripping out of bits and pieces of the world as they painted an exceptionally bleak picture in an already oppressively eerie game.

Among the Sleep isn't without its flaws; there are moments when its gameplay becomes too shallow even for how deliberately designed it is to be that way, the voice acting ranges from acceptable to weird, and many of the textures can be shockingly muddy. But what it's trying to be, and in most ways entirely succeeds, is something that will stick with me long after the credits finish and I sit in the dark hoping the child I'd been playing as finds better days to come.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
The simple act of presenting a game through the eyes of a toddler is ingenious. Not too long ago Bioshock 2 gave us a somewhat exaggerated and short taste of what it might be like wondering around madness as a small child. Among the Sleep stumbles a bit in game design, but it does have something new to offer.

The opening finds you staring through a distorted glass before you drop your cup and your mom comes in to feed you cake. Someone knocks on the door, and as she leaves the room, her raised voice is heard which cues the visuals and sound to intensify until she returns to carry you of to your room. What is being displayed in this sequence is an almost innate pang or irritation that swells up when a parent is upset. Among the Sleep then follows this sequence by setting players firmly into their toddler limbs with quick crib escape in order to introduce the young protagonist to  a cordial, talking teddy bear who attempts to rid the child of fear. It is quite the opening. The child's comforts are made clear through the mother and friend, as are his limitations and abilities with his toys and Brobdingnagian world of everyday objects and furniture. Among the Sleep attempts to carry these motifs throughout the game through various objects and designs from eerie coats and countless doors to the memories of happiness the child must find. While these are nice ideas, there are some hiccups in gameplay that mar the experience a bit.

Among the Sleep is marketed as a horror game, which means that the surprise is somewhat ruined as people will now be searching for scares. It is also this focus on horror that takes away power from the monsters in the game. Horror is the visceral, the monsters, or Carpenter's The Thing in the flesh; terror is more of what we build up in our minds, the monsters we imagine when the lights flicker or the floorboards creak. Among the Sleep crafts terror expertly with the humming of a TV and the dancing of shadows, but it is the actual sight of the monsters that take away the power they had. This is no slight against the monster's design, because good monsters are hard to make; in general whatever we imagine in our own head will probably be scarier than what an artist can represent. Pushing the player to face a monster that is in fact not as creepy as the atmosphere the game created so well, is a misstep.

The game's pacing is a bit uneven. The structure of returning to a home and filling it with memories is understandable, if a little heavy handed, but these bits of going to the little home come off as more of a chore. There were also some areas, such as the swamp section, that were easy to get lost in because everything looked the same. Some large areas with lots of climbable objects seemed suspiciously designed to take up more time than necessary. The game's sense of style really seemed to shine when it was recreating the real and only adding in bits of distortion, but most of the game is filled with wildly warped areas that did not appeal to me as much.

Time is also another important issue with Among the Sleep. Standing at only a few hours with the middle area dragging a bit is a rough edge. The game is not that challenging ( though I did have a monster sneak up on a me few times, and I did fall off a bridge more than once which sent me back further than I would have liked) and there is very little interaction or gameplay involved: you crawl around and climb to your heart's content with little consequence and with not much else to do aside from grab key items. The lack of player involvement stacks on with the pacing issue.

Among the Sleep is not perfect, but it is an interesting game. Some sections should probably have been longer while others could have been trimmed away. The shift in settings might be welcome for some, but I rather liked the hints of imagination at play. Aside from the minor gripes, it is an enjoyable game. There are definitely some elements in Among the Sleep that I hope to see in other games.

Another long-ish one I think, ladies and jellybeans.

This is the first horror game that I have played, and despite the fact horror games usually don‚Äôt seem that appealing to me, Among the Sleep was the first to actually get me to buy and try.

Of course the main appeal to this game, at least in my opinion, is the quite dramatic perception change compared to usual games. You play as a little 2 year old boy, who can barely walk, whose outlook on life is a lot different to us adults. It‚Äôs actually pretty cool being so small and everything around you that in normal situations wouldn‚Äôt be a problem, suddenly become a challenge.

This game is also very surreal, at times I definitely got a ‚ÄúAlice: Madness Returns‚Äù feeling from it. You aren‚Äôt quite sure what is going on at times and it is never really spelt out for you, so on a certain level, this game is open to interpretation. It has a strong message to it, but the way that it was done and the details about the game make you wonder.

The level design was quite creative, the general mechanics are all the same for how the baby gets around, but each level had a different thing going on. It wasn‚Äôt too repetitive and of course that works in its favour.

Horror wise, someone that suffers with anxiety problems like myself would definitely get a little worked up playing this. The ambient sounds and noises are definitely enough to rustle those jimmies and it definitely caught me out a few times making me jump. But like I mentioned before, I don‚Äôt exactly play many horror games so I wouldn‚Äôt know what those Horror veterans strive for. Compared to other games maybe this isn‚Äôt scariest game of the year, but it is definitely creepy.

I think the only thing about this game people might not be so happy about would be its length. I personally don‚Äôt mind short games, I have a short attention span and I think as long as the game has core strengths to it, I‚Äôm happy with it being short and sweet. But other people maybe not so much. It took me 3 hours to finish the game (and start a new one to go back for 1 achievement) but it definitely felt shorter.

TL;DR : All in all, this game has an interesting story, great atmosphere and the tiny-man‚Äôs perception is new and refreshing for any game let alone horrors. Only fault being it was pretty short (for most people, I would assume).

The art and level design of the game really stands out overall. Twisted but familiar the levels of the game never feel like they are repeating and the developers took great care in crafting each and every part of them. It was fun just exploring the levels (like a child) just to see what little bits they had hidden around.
The puzzles aren't hard at all and or pretty much "Find item X to open door" but the search for the key never feels tedious or repetitive since there is always new places to explore. I often ended up finding a key to a door before finding the door due to me having fun wandering around.

The monsters feels very much like part of the world. It is familiar but also very twisted. Throughout the game you start to discover what the creatures are but that doesn't make it less scary and only enroots it to the world the developers have made.

The game is about 3 hours long
recommended: shorter if you just run around as fast as you can without taking the time to look around but its a great 3 hours. This is a quality game that deserves to be in everyone's library even for people like me who are not fans of horror."

reviewText:
The survival horror genre has an identity crisis as of late. Capcom pumps out action titles, calls them Resident Evil and somehow they get classified as survival horror. I miss the classic survival horror titles like Silent Hill and Eternal Darkness. There was hope of a revitalization with Kojima‚Äôs P.T. but that ended before it could even get started. Enter Among the Sleep from Killbrite Studio and after a few trailers I thought this could finally be the survival horror return I‚Äôve been waiting for. Does Among the Sleep deliver, and is it truly survival horror?

Among the Sleep takes you through a trippy adventure told through the eyes of a two year old as he tries to find his mother, preventing you from achieving this is a shadow like individual (very similar to Slender Man). Not only that but you have a companion talking stuffed teddy bear (named Teddy for obvious reasons). How could this not be a survival horror title?

Like I said earlier, Among the Sleep is told through the eyes of a toddler and I mean that literally. This is a first person toddler title and through your adventure you will crawl, climb and kinda run. While also picking up objects such as drawings and other children‚Äôs toys along the way. Among the Sleep is not a very long game; clocking in around 3 hours. I really don‚Äôt want to dive into the stages involved in the game for spoiler purposes. I will say you get to explore the child‚Äôs house rather early in the game and this is where the game starts you down the rabbit hole on its eerie nightmarish adventure.

Basic controls involve; crawling, grabbing items (holding items has them float in air which reminds me of Half-Life) and hugging Teddy to lighten up areas as well as calm the toddler down. Controls and gameplay are very basic and honestly that's not what‚Äôs important about Among the Sleep. The atmosphere and musical score is what I was looking forward to most, and in my opinion it is the most crucial part of any survival horror title. So I‚Äôm happy to report that while the game is very short, the environments and mood throughout really enhanced the storytelling experience. Playing Among the Sleep with the lights off will deliver more creeps and scares than Capcom has been able to deliver with any Resident Evil title for the past 10 years.

Among the Sleep is a baby step (see what I did there) in the right direction when it comes to the survival horror genre. It‚Äôs an original concept and a very unique experience. Not to sound like a broken record, but Among the Sleep feels like it‚Äôs over just as it‚Äôs getting into its groove and that‚Äôs really my only major complaint. Hopefully this isn‚Äôt Killbrite Studio‚Äôs only entry into the survival horror genre because I would love to see what else they could pull off with a longer story and bigger budget.

reviewText:
I'm a newbie to gamey horror, in fact I think this is my first 'pure' horror game. Closest things are the Master Reboot and F.E.A.R. series. Scariest experience was the hotel in VtM:R: Bloodlines. So I am rating this game from this point of view. If you are a seasoned spookymans player then this could be a boring baby simulator for all I know.

In this game you play as a toddler accompanied by a talking bear (who doesn't turn out to be a pawn of Satan as I predicted the moment I met him) and you'll have to achieve your goal by going through a world too big for you.

Gameplay itself is mostly walking, climbing on stuff and some very simple puzzles. You can walk upright and sprint like that for short distances, or you can baby-crawl. Instead of a flashlight you hug your bear.

The 'horror' is mostly achieved with atmosphere and ~spooky~ stuff happening, there are no screamers or monsters rushing at you. The (for me) scariest part was just at the beginning and I'm sure there is not even a 'monster' in that part.

Speaking of monsters, there are two that I saw (plus one in the Prologue), and many that I imagined. I can't really describe them as I didn't want to look at them, and only took better glimpses from a distance. Hiding from them is easy and I don't know what happens if you're caught as I avoided it. But I think that 'being easy' is a very good thing in a horror game, as imagining what would happen to you is scarier than being torn apart or eaten or whatever a monster would do to you. And when the scary goblin rips you apart for the fifth time, there's not even a shred of horror left.

The story is quite predictable (judging from me, a dumbass, figuring it out) and in the end you will be beaten to the head with it, in case you didn't get it. But the matter is handled quite well I'd say.

Graphically the game is good, considering it's an indie kickstarted game. Some sceneries are even stunning.

The free DLC Prologue is quite cool also, although I had a problem with the monster being stuck in front of my hiding place so I had to retry from last save point, which wasn't a setback at all, honestly.

Note that the game is very short, even with the free DLC you can finish it in around 2,5 hours.


1 solid spooky golden sloth.

reviewText:
This was a pretty unique game. You are playing as a two year old whose birthday it is. Your mom givse you a teddy bear, but then something happens that cause her to get freaked out and puts you in your room while I suppose she is dealing with it. You and your now animate teddy go on a little adventure at which point your mom realizes you got out of your playpen and puts you to bed for the night. You hear somethign and start to wake up. Your teddy is taken from you and your crib knocked over, which is where the real adventure begins.

This is a horror game as seen through the eyes of a two year old, and it brilliantly handles this through creepy sights and sounds and some ambiguous monster that starts to hunt for you as the story progresses.

There are a couple times where you will jump a little, but it isnt really a scary game per se. It is however creepy, and the subject matter is quite dark and depressing. The end is both sad and hopeful all at once.

I will say without giving anythign away that this topic will be relevant and quite poignant for a lot of people, and it may even be the sort of game that brings real tears to you depending on your own set of circumstances growing up. While I didnt experience the things that happen in this game, I can appreciate how much this might affect some people.

Outside of that, the adventure is filled with mystery and awe.

I think this was a very well made game that also handled a sensitive topic quite well and did an amazing job of bringing the world as seen through two year old eyes to life perfectly.

This one is a 10/10 for sure.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a first-person horror game where you play as a Toddler. The game is a bit more of an experience game, or if you will, a 'Crawling Simulator', though there are a few physics-based puzzles, and a few occasional sections where you get stalked by a monster.

It's your second birthday, and your mom has given you a teddy bear for this special occasion. However, when left on your own in your playpen, the bear begins to move and talk on its own devices. Soon it tells you it wants to show you something, but you need to be in the dark...

As a toddler, you can crawl, walk, and run a bit (though running for a while will make you trip). Crawling is faster than walking, and you can fit under tight spaces, but walking let's you see more and interact with higher-things. There are a variety of objects to interact with and pick-up in your environment, and the physics of objects are all pretty well handled. You can also climb up onto objects that are waist-high for you.

With these mechanics, you are let off to explore and interact with things to progress. The first half of the game is more of a straight-up 'Crawling Simulator' type of game, as while there are some small puzzles and some good atmosphere, nothing really comes to hunt you... That is, until the second half of the game.

Sound design is top-notch. The music is appropriately odd and somewhat mystical, but what really needs to be mentioned is environment sounds. As a 2-year old, the world is still a foreign and strange place, and sounds we as adults find familiar take on strange properties through the imagination  of a child. The sound design is legitimately unnerving and creepy, and is honestly one of the first horror games in a long while that I've been this impressed with how it handled its sound design. It leans perfectly on the thin line between the familiar and the strange and terrifying.

Graphics and art direction also deserve mention. The game looks good, with a sort of unique creepy cartoony-fantasy look that really fits the tone of the game. The art direction is also extremely well handled, especially in the later locations, and contain a lot of imagination and visual imagery that is easy to stick with you. The game gets more surreal as it goes on, and gets more twisted, and the imaginative art direction makes quite a few visual splendors to behold.

Scariness is subjective, but while the game could of maybe been scarier with a few more tricks, I would say it did manage to unnerve me, surprise me, and tense me up on a few occasions. The sound design made me not want to continue every now and again, and the few encounters with monsters were appropriately tense and scary.

But the monster encounters are very few, which is both in my eyes a good thing and a bad thing. On one hand, the two different monsters the game has never became overly familiar due to how infrequent they were, and both managed to really tense things-up whenever they did appear, and provided interesting challenges and context to situations. But on the other hand, there were many sections, especially in the middle part of the game, where I felt a little too safe.

The game maybe could of dared to be a little scarier and explore a few of the possibilities it raises with it's fantastic atmosphere and a few implied danger scenarios that don't actually lead into anything, but arguably its infrequent quality is what helps the game stay tense.

The story was interesting, while not entirely too surprising, I would say that it was handled rather well. Some nice use of symbolism throughout.

But it's one flaw is that it's rather short, being about 2-4 hours long. Those two to four hours are rather well-done, but it did leave me wanting more at it's conclusion, and some may not want to pay $20 for a 2-4 hour experience.

But Among the Sleep is a good little horror game that will likely stick with you some after completing it. It doesn't rely overly on jump scares, and unnerves with atmosphere, fantastic sound design, strange moments, and a few infrequent monster encounters. It's short and sweet, and will likely be appreciated by fans of 'Walking Simulator Experience' type of games with a little more gameplay, and horror fan who especially appreciate atmosphere.

reviewText:
Amnesia:Early Years

Among the Sleep brings out the best of horror/adventure/puzzlesque genre.

First thing you have to realize, you play for a two years old kid. You are not very fast, neither tall and of course everything is from his point of view so scary things can be more scarier.
This (for me) original concept, thrives on stunning level design where children nightmares become reality, where every sound creeps me out, and where biggest fear comes from unknown evil.
As we progress further and further, we're recovering earliest happy memories, while environment around us hinting, that every one of these memories are hiding terrible truth from us.
Ending sequence is somewhat heartbreaking and it added another layer to story - emotional this time.

Among the Sleep is game of high quality. It has amazing atmosphere, terrifying moments as well as emotional impact.
I strongly recommend to give this game a try.

8.5/10

reviewText:
In Among the Sleep you take control of a two-year old child. The game starts with an opening scene where you celebrate your second birthday. Your mum feeds you some cake before taking you upstairs with a birthday present delivered by someone who your mother does not invite in (maybe the father). The gift turns out to be a teddy bear, which comes to life and acts as your guide throughout the game. Shortly after you are off to bed, you wake up in the middle of the night to your cot being dragged across the room before tumbling over. After some wondering you realize that your Mummy is not in her bed and you set off on an adventure of sorts to find her again. It is clear that you are in a dream world but the further you go into the game, the darker it becomes.
The control system is good. You have two main modes of getting around, walking and crawling. Crawling is faster, but you ca not carry anything or hug your teddy (he gives you light when you do so). While walking you are slower but from the standing position you can climb up onto furniture and boxes. In fact all the animations throughout the game are good. A cool little feature is when you pause the game, the child brings his hands up to cover his eyes.
The graphics are good so far, could be a few more details but nothing big to complain.
Sound plays a huge part in the game. Teddy will talk to you sometimes to help guide you through the story but usually you are listening to the sound of your mum humming a lullaby with you trying to head towards the source. Also you can hear some eerie music, creaky doors or floorboards or other objects moving or falling.
The game itself is too short. I finished it within 109 minutes.
Among the Sleep is not scary at all but it has a great atmosphere. The ending of the game is pretty shocking. I will not tell you anything, you have to play and see it by yourself.
I can recommend Among the Sleep but you should wait for a discount, 19,99‚Ç¨ is a bit too much for only around 110 minutes of gaming.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 7/10
Atmosphere 10/10

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a cleverly written survival horror game developed by Norwegians. It is a unique little game in the sense that the protagonist is a two-year-old little boy who's aided by his Teddy bear in order to go through various horrors that are lurking in their house.

The story begins with a birthday celebration that reveals Teddy to be the gift. However, he is taken from the boy and in chapter 1 we need to retrieve him quickly only to realise that the real protection from the dark can only be offered by mom. The journey then continues to find mom and along the way we encounter some monsters and cleverly thought out puzzles.

The game has a great atmosphere and for full immersion a headset is required - similarly to the Amnesia games. The Unity engine does its job properly and the visuals look great. The only downside is the game's short story: it can be completed in a mere 2 hours including its DLC content which is a kind of prologue and is meant to be played after the story is done.

Overall, Among the Sleep is a good game that I can recommend mainly to the fans of the genre. Hopefully, the guys at Krillbite Studios will develop a - much longer - sequel or another game with similar level of quality.

UPDATE: The latest update (version number 2) introduces some new achievements (all related to collectibles) along with some nice graphics enhancements thanks to the new version of the Unity engine.

reviewText:
Once again, Krillbite studio has brought us on a thought provoking adventure. Their first being The Plan, which was a 'preview' of their first shot at developing with the Unity engine... and quite frankly changed my view of what defines a good game in a matter of 2 minutes time.

It seems that this small group of developers has a knack of thinking outside of the box. Again using the Unity engine, Among the Sleep puts you in the unique position of viewing the world through the eyes of a two year old. Never before has a lovable protagonist been so helpless. Using this gameplay method in a horror game is a stroke of genious, since you have no way of defending yourself against unknown evils. It really adds to the feeling of helplessness. Periodic jumpscares plus extraordinary psychologically tense background noise creates an unnerving edge-of-your seat venture.

This game is not without its flaws. Glitches abound, and the the monotone surroundings feel clausterphobic at times. I also found that for the price, it was surprisingly short.This game could use some depth and length, but all in all, it was a very unique experience that I would recommend for gamers who enjoy something new. 8/10.

Only an hour or so into the game but already enjoying it, its nice to see a new take on the horror genre.

reviewText:
I remember my first teddy bear when I was a little girl. His name was Rufus. He was actually my best friend for a long time until I was able to imagine friends without the need of a physical face.

He still huddles among the boots of my closet, negotiating with all the sock-monsters in there.

For many children, the security of a soft, cuddly friend can really make or break their day, and there is something incredibly endearing in being able to experience this through the eyes of a toddler, as an adult.


The knowledge that such simple things seem so terrifying at such a young age, makes complete sense when you understand that a child's mind is bursting with unbridled creativity.


- I recommend you play with headphones for full immersion.


As a whole, I loved this game.The storyline was surprisingly refreshing - it's odd how stereotypical visions have a tendency to creep up on your subconscious, grab you by the heels and shout 'Gotcha!' even when you think you have them equalled.


- Short and sweet. My only complaint to be that it could have been a little longer, though there is an epilogue that I also recommend playing through.


SO many cuddles for Teddy.

If you have a few hours to spare, I suggest trying out Among the Sleep.

reviewText:
I should sleep.  Somewhere among the sleep is me, half awake and bufuddled.  The barely awake dad who has to see what is terrifying my 2 year old at 3AM.  Those dark hallways with toys everywhere, been there. *You* try walking through that minefield of balls, dolls, and wooden blocks.  But I've seen the terror in thier eyes, tears falling and crying out frantically for someone to make them feel safe again.  And in no other game has it ever been recreated with such clarity.

In this game you are two years old again.  Toddling long.  Crawling is faster.  Exploring the hidden world that always seems foreboding.  Mundane objects take on a menacing appearance, unknown sounds all the more spine chilling.  And also in this game, there is a tone of something else.  Alcohol bottles strewn across the floor.  Refridgerator doors left wide open.  In the world of Among the Sleep you must traverse the completely believeable household universe of two year old terror.

Gameplay is mostly interacting with objects, some simple puzzles.  You travel through some toddler nightmare lands collecting items to fit in a slot, or solving a way to smash open a toy chest.  Then a bit of cat and mouse chases with a monster that looms nearby, searching for you.  Seeking you out all the time.

Visually, it's quite well done and a lot of attention to game detail with shadow and specific uses of color.  I played with both a KB&M and Controller, both work very well.  No in game crashes for me and I never got stuck on geometry or bugs.

I have to add, that although this is a horror game, you are limited the horror of a two year old.  It's not a gorefest of a demon infested graveyard waiting for you, it's a  playground with ledges and hiding holes, spooky libraries, or being chased in a coat closet.  These are familiar areas to most of us and it may or may not frighten you.  I would say for those who cannot endure most horror games, this is substanially less anxiety causing.  Perhaps with some, it may hit a few heartstrings which you will discover later towards the end.

The game is a story more than anything.  Not a visual novel or a game with lots of in-game dialogue, but a storytelling nonetheless.  And at the end, you'll see what the true terror is that plagues our little character.  The full game is a little short. After I was done I played the DLC which is also short where you save your plush toys from the cold, but a little scarier than the main game.  Among the sleep is a good game, a gamble really in this age of horror games.  And it's well done.   At $20 I personally think that it's pricey.  I got this in a bundle, though, and think it was money well spent.

Forgot to add - in the kitchen I spent a good bit of time destroying everything I could get my little hands on.  Wreaking the dishes and lobbing a coffee maker off the counter was bliss. Destruco-Toddler skill points +10.  Cheers.

reviewText:
Among The Sleep disappointed me in many ways. First, we were promised that the game would last up to 3 hours. I finished it in 90 minutes. In the end I can't blame no one but myself. If a developer says it's this big, it's usually a couple of hours shorter. My bad. Second, we were told this would be a horror game, but it didn't scare me for one second, even if some of the chases creeped me out.
So there's that, and the fact that there isn't much exploration to do, and if you do find things that pique your interest they usually can't be interacted with.

But, there are some good things to say about the game. The textures, for example, are sharp and the graphics are, at times, colorful, Something you don't see very often in horror games. The voice acting is also pretty good and the way that you see things through the eyes of a 2 year old is different (it has a bit of a fisheye effect) and well done. Pressing escape is also a cute way to bring up the menu. And running for too long will make you fall on your hands and feet. Small little details that I can always appreciate, no matter if the game is good or bad. The story is actually pretty good, too. Good, but predictable.

But... I just can't recommend this. I would absolutely recommend this if it cost ‚Ç¨10 or less, but asking twice as much is outrageous for a game that can be finished in one sitting. To be honest... I feel a bit ripped off. And that's not a feeling that I have very often. So my advice would to be to wait for a sale. Just give it a few weeks/months.

reviewText:
First, the bad: its short. Even with the free DLC extra chapter, its short... like under 4 hours short. There is not a ton of replay value unless you get drawn into the story and want to go back to see little meta-clues and child-drawings you missed. The couple of graphical glitches, overlapping lighting through doors, odd seeing through objects at odd angles... not bad honestly, and definitely not game-breaking.

The good: this is a rather well told dark story, and seeing it explored through the body of a 2-yr old child is a very unique approach to telling it. Your adult-brain logic being used to guide the character through the puzzles and tale aside, they've done quite a good job of making you feel like you're interacting through a toddler. As a small child you are clumsy, slow, very poorly armed and armored against the shadows that crawl along the walls and roar out through the dark... your only defense is to hide and find comfort in the warmth in your teddybear guide and traveling companion.

There are a few jumpscares, but absolutely no gore... this game uses nothing but unease, shadows and noises, the surreality of childhood nightmares and exagerations, and the inherent helplessness of your character as the basis for it's horror. A significant part of the entire storyline involves some well written emotional manipulation; if you play these kinds of games in any sort of emersive mind-set (or you're just kinda over-emotional like I can be), you will get a far greater experience from this game. You'll be motivated to help the child through this journey, feel afraid of the creepiness of this world, and seeing the tale through the end will feel rather moving in bad and good ways... potentially triggery ways, depending on your own childhood...

If you don't do emersive gaming, if you dont allow yourself to play these kinds of games as if you were nervous about the surroundings, if you just plow through these kinds of hide-from-the-monster horror games... this will be a short game with not much meat on it, and you will likely feel more dissapointed than profound.

Recommended to purchase on sale. Despite the effort and atmosphere that obviously went into the game, the full price of $20 is just a little bit steep for the length.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Review
What would you do if you were two years old and you were awoken abruply in the middle of the night?
You'd look for your mom, of course!

This is how Among the Sleep begins.
You're just two years old, took your bottle, ate some cake, won a cute Teddy bear, went to bed and you're abruptly awoken in the middle of the night.
Time to look for mommy!
However, the search for your mom's arms will be terrifying.
Through basic controls like walking, crawling, grabbing items, running (or trying to) and hugging your Teddy bear, you'll face creepy noises, puzzles and will hide from unkillable enemies.

You should play it in a dark room and don't forget your headphones!
Explore the environment, the rooms, play close attention to the noises and if something goes wrong, squeeze your Teddy bear, he'll light your way!

If you enjoyed Papo & Yo you'll probably enjoy Among the Sleep.

Rating:
9/10

reviewText: Awesome game!  The story
date:
foreshadowing, unique gameplay, atmosphere and clever level design are all presented well in this game.  The only downside is the length, even though it feels appropriate given the lack of gameplay mechanics the  devs had to work with.

The cleverness to the scare tactics was genius.  Just like when I was a kid, it was the unknown that scared me the most.  So much of this game works on the player's imagination instead of cheap jump-scares.  In a lot of horror games, it is common to start predicting the scary section which can often soften the blow.  Not in this game.  The ambiance is done  well enough that the anticipation of a predictable scare actually makes it worse.  Kind of like being in a dream and knowing that it's going bad.

They did such a good job with the sound effects.  The bumps, creaks, groans, smashes, screams and cries all drive the unsettled nerves home.

The devs also did an excellent job making you feel as helpless as a two year old child.  The toddler can crawl faster than walk, he will fall over if he sprints for more than a short distance, his light source is a teddy-bear that lights up when hugged, water is a nono, everything seems much larger and daunting, he can't reach doorknobs without something to climb on, and his lack of fine motor skills makes the clunkyness of click and hold" mouse interactions feel right.

The foreshadowing is great.  A lot of the clues you get to the story are in the environment or depicted as a two-year-old's scribbled drawing.

Though the  length is short but feels accurate for the game
recommended: it is hard to say that a 3-4 hour game with little to no replay value  should be $20.  The reason why I say that it has  no replay value is the fact that the game relies so heavily on the unknown and the imagination for the fear to work

reviewText:
Title: Among the Sleep
Genre:  Action, Adventure, Indie
Developer:  Krillbite Studio
Publisher: Krillbite Studio
Release Date: 29th May 2014

TL;DR, VerdictReally interesting premise for a horror game. Takes camera away from you a lot so motion sickness can be an issue. Worth the play if you want something a little different from typical horrors.
*Note as a motion sickness gamer I will keep trying to play this game because I do like it.*
P.S : this game made sure I looked suspicious  to my teddy

Pros

Good voice acting
Good atmosphere and sounds
Bright, contrasting environments for your main character, the sort of colours you expect to see in a small child's room

Cons

If you have video game motion sickness, don't play this

Gameplay
This game focuses on a toddler's view of the world, and how their active imagination distorts things and makes things more unsettling. You start off looking into the bottom of a glass, except the effect is confusing - just like how a toddler must feel when interacting with so many new objects and unfamiliar environments. The music in the background and the mother's crooning voice makes the game unnerving for something that everyone does to their children.

The screen sometimes shakes and despite the normal settings of the game, ordinary things are made more nightmarish by your baby's first person viewpoint and way of looking at the world. Almost everything can have a sinister undertone to it.

When you have full control of the baby you prefer to crawl around for speed rather than walk, and you interact with the objects and environment around you. And the teddy bear.

The voice acting is quite good, the speakers to your baby all use that special voice  reserved for small children or cute animals.  You're not sure if your teddy bear is evil or not. He makes you hide in a dark closet, and you have to hug the teddy to ‚Äúlight‚Äù up the area, and make it less scary. Except it doesn't work out like that. The voice acting and noises help to make a perfectly normal environment scarier than it should be, as if your character is isolated and alone in their world. And mother is a potential enemy. And teddy is either your last resort or your worst friend.

I like the fact this game really plays on the feeling of a kid's active imagination. Monsters in the dark, sounds you don't recognise, everything being exaggerated out of proportion.
I struggled to keep playing this game though I liked it. It's not a good game for those who suffer from video game motion sickness.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a First Person horror/puzzle game in where we play as a toddler trying to find his mother in a dark and twisted world. We start off in our birthday party, eat some cake with our mom and are given a terrifying teddy bear as a gift. The bear teaches us the basics of the game such as picking stuff up and climbing but you may be half expecting it to murder you at any given moment. Surprisingly that creepy as sin stuffed bear turns out to be your best friend throughout this ordeal and doubles as a flashlight whenever you hug it. The voice actor that plays the teddy bear has a very calm and soothing voice which ironically enough adds to the creepiness of it.

Everything is all well and normal until you go to sleep and have your crib flipped over by an invisible entity. From there on out the world turns pretty twisted and has no sense of coherency sort of like a dream as the ways the areas connect to each other make no sense. Not much will make sense actually as the story is quite cryptic and you will have to piece it together yourself. As strange as the world is the level design is linear and well thought out so you should never find yourself lost. Most of the story is also told through the environment so there is a reason to pay attention to your surroundings other than the possibility of death.

A large portion of your time will be solving very simple puzzles to be able to progress to the next area but there are a few stealth sections where you must hide and avoid monsters. These are definitely the low points of the game as it can be hard to indicate when the monster is near until you catch a glimpse but by then you will be killed. They just hold you up in the air and show a game over screen so don't expect violent baby executions buying this. Another problem with having to avoid the monsters is that your fat baby legs are nowhere near agile enough to move to cover quickly. As mentioned before these sections are few and far between so it doesn't really have much of an impact to the experience.

When you are standing you will be able to run shortly before falling down and reverting back to your crawling stance. Crawling allows you to fit into tiny locations and is much faster than walking but you are unable to hug the teddy bear for light and since you can also run when standing there is little reason to crawl. You can also climb on objects to reach places. An example being pulling up a chair and climbing it to reach a door knob. You can also pick up objects and throw them but throwing doesn't really become a factor until much later on. The baby is surprisingly strong considering how hard he throws objects and is able to move chairs without a problem.

I'd imagine you are not considering purchasing this game for the cool physics or the puzzles but for the horror. Among the Sleep pulls it off pretty well and being a toddler really helps as everything in the world seems big and scary. This isn't really the kind of game that will throw jump-scares at you around every corner. Jump-scares are rare for the most part and the game instead relies heavily on subtle psychological horror such as dimly lit rooms, objects falling and distant noises. One thing that I found separated it from most horror games is the lack of blood, gore or violence. It is definitely a breath of fresh air and shows you can make an unnerving experience without resorting to gross out tactics.

The audio in Among the Sleep really amplifies the horror. It does a very good job at making you paranoid through use of sudden thumps, braking glass and just tense ambient music. Without such good sound effects and ambiance the game would have been much less effective at horror. Environments are unique and have the advantage of really making you feel like a small defenseless toddler in a over-sized world. Graphics are pretty good as well and I found it impressive how environments went from breathtaking to horrifying in some areas. Levels don't actually interconnect in any real way other than you sliding down a rusty pipe into a new location but it does end up adding to the surreal nature of it all.

Overall this is a pretty good horror title. It does lack in gameplay and the puzzles are so easy that they will not offer any challenge and may feel like they are there just to give you something to do. Though considering the game is only two hours you will likely finish the game before boredom or repetition sets in. The horror does stay unpredictable throughout and they do a really good job at sparingly using the monsters to hunt you. Among the Sleep doesn't feel like a glorified game of hide and seek like other modern horror titles, instead it feels like a very personal experience through the warped mind of a toddler. It really does feel like a walking simulator with puzzles thrown in to slow you down but if you are fine with that there is a truly memorable and unique experience here that will remain in your mind long after you beat it.

The game itself is okay. The concept is interesting, and the atmosphere and horror aspects are well executed.

There's just one problem:

It's one hour long.

Wait for it to go on sale for under $10. Just because this was a kickstarter project doesn't make it an excuse to make you pay this much.

reviewText:
This review contains a couple of mere spoilers.

Among the Sleep has a very impressive affect on the player. It shows the great idea that only a genius could think of - using the perspective of a baby. Throughout this baby perspective, we can clearly notice that the baby has worries over many things like their mother's scream. At the beginning of the game, the character's mother goes to answer the door that had just had the doorbell ring. The mother then screams which queues the music and visual effects to give a dramatic effect. This happens to show that the baby feels stressed and panicked as though the mother is giving a distress call - an in-danger tone. I find this is a very creative idea and the creator really understands how emotion is built up in a game.

After seeing the monster, I have a slight lust of disappointment, for as soon as a monster is shown in a game, that ruins the horror element of a build up. No studios are able to create a monster that is more horrifying that what we, as consumers, create in our head from mysterious build-ups, such as lighting effects and creaky floorboards. As soon as a monster is shown in a game, it automatically drops some tension and makes the player less scared of the monster. This game has lost the horrific momentum by showing the monster, and the monster doesn't look very scary, but I guess there are limits as to how scary you can make a monster look. And to be quite straight... what is a monster? A monster is a horrific creature or person that is created IN OUT HEADS by dramatic effects and noises. Making a monster be shown in a game really doesn't make it a monster anymore.

The teddy bear's voice acting and sounds are very good. The sound effects successfully create tension and the teddy bear successfully sounds like a Paedophile - I mean a nice friend.  In addition, the animations of movement in the game are very smooth, however are a little slow and... the opposite of slick. Whatever that word is.

As far as I can judge on the game mechanics, they are quite simple and not all that amazing. Animations for the things the character uses are very simple and could be improved through more time in development.

I do believe this game has a really good story line, really good twists and successfully shows the in-depth perspective of a baby in every-day situations. Among the Sleep shows a definite prime example of what a baby would think about as they go to sleep on a dark, windy night. It shows how the baby is petrified and shows how simple things are over-exaggerated in the baby's mind, such as a wardrobe.

Overall, I think this game really is worth the play and if you don't play this game, you'd be missing out on a lot of interesting perspective.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep Review -NO SPOILERS!-(except for the part about the footie pajamas)


Among the Sleep is a unique game that is played in the innocent eyes of a young child. I enjoyed this game - not only because of the horror element, which was very well done - but also because it told a valuable and emotional story with only a few words. In the minds of toddlers, many things and situations that happen in their lives sometimes don‚Äôt make sense. This game did a great job ‚Äútranslating‚Äù what was really happening into something that a toddler would see and understand. Moreover, it was absolutely terrifying. Many things make this game unique and different from most other first person games. First of all, the only way to transport yourself is toddling or crawling-which can make running away from certain death quite tense at times. Second, you play only two feet from the ground making everything around huge and curious. Third, you can see your body if you look down! You‚Äôre not a floating head bobbing around! Also, the baby footie pajamas are very nice. There will never be a dull moment when this incredible game is played and it may or may not make one speechless for a few days. I recommend it for anyone who is looking for a clean and eerie game that has good morals and lessons to be learned - including not making a single noise. There is one thing all must know when playing this: don‚Äôt break a bottle.

reviewText:
Honestly, Among the Sleep is captivating on many levels. I personally love horror games and while this game definitely had its moments of jump scare, it was nothing like other games in the genre (Amnesia or Outlast just to name a few), but considering the powerful story they tell perhaps its good they aren't like the others. The subtle way the writers work in real adult issues in the eyes of a 2 year old is impressive, as well as scary. The story reaches a depth that I sometimes don't see in a game with 60 hours worth of campaign, and deserves a lot of credit for it. The game takes you through a fantastic story that leaves you exposed and vulnerable. Definitely a great Indie story in a mild horror game.

PROLOGUE:

The prologue is a short add on to clear up part of the story that a lot of people might not have picked up on in the original game alone. Neither of your parents are perfect.

reviewText:
As much as I wanted to like this, I found myself wishing for the end of the game and given that it's a short game anyway, that's not so good.  Whilst there are some well done / clever moments and the designer did a great job of making the change of perspective into something that was a little overwhelming and scary, the experience was more of a walking (crawling?) simulator with a rather overblown story.

For a horror, it was more creepy than scary and the 'monsters' were very much more of an irritant that something to fear.  This was partly due to the poor AI presenting very little challenge, but also grinding visual and audio effects that made me want to go brew a cuppa whilst I waited for them to pass.

Similarly, puzzles were unchallenging - pretty much 'pull this to free this' and 'move this then jump on it', wrapped up in fetch quests.  Not that other horror games don't do unchallenging, but Among the Sleep isn't distracting you with the anticipation of terrifying things happening.  There are plenty of pretty bits, some very nice alice moments and the aforementioned change of perspective, but it's just not enough.  Not at fifteen quid a go.

reviewText:
Okay, okay. For all those kids out there that think it's one or two hours of gameplay, get real. Why do you even play games, if you are in such a rush to finish them? Think of this as a great film... I got four to five hours out of it. Yes, 20 is a bit much... but if I am lucky, the Dlc will be free. (Right.) Anyway, to those of you that think this is going to change the way you play. NOOOOOOO! The story is genius, to me at least. You won't understand how brilliant it is if you are just a kid. This is aimed at adults and if you have children or grew up in a bad home, it will make sense. To everybody else, you'll be wondering why you never get to kill anybody. Grow up, then come back to this.

This game really is brilliant and should be played by anybody who has children. It is not perfect, not even close, but it does tell a very important story that is sad, scary and beautiful. I know not a lot of people are willing to admit when a game spooks them or makes them feel uneasy, yet I will tell you this, I was spooked out by a part in this more than any other game I have ever played.

Now, this is best played with headphones on in the dark. A lot of reviews spoiled some of the most intense moments, so dont read too much into the story. The graphics are nothing special, but they do the job and the enviroments are nice to look at. I also found the creature to be well designed.

The puzzles are far too easy and end up being things that just slow you down more than test your wits. Still, the story and atmosphere are amazing. The real let down is the price since this game is very short and doesn't bring anything new to the table. If you catch it on offer, it is a must own.

reviewText:
Great game. But way too short.

Graphics are fine. Could be a little better. But it's still nice to look at.
Sound is alright. Some cute sounds here and there. And the atmosphere sounds are done fairly decently.
Story is an interesting take on horrors. It's very simple though. Nothing fancy. Kind of leaves you with some questions.
Gameplay itself is simple but fun. Though very very easy.

But the killer of this game is the price and it's extremely short storyline. You can finish this within an hour to two hours with ease. There is no challenge and the scares are well... not so scary. They are quite simple and predictable. Nothing fancy. So chances are if you're used to horrors, you won't really get much of a scare out of this. The only thing I had was a few jump scares. But there was very little suspense for me.

There is not really any replayability either on this. The game had far more potential to really be a powerful game with a deep story, proper scares and indepth gameplay. But sadly this did not happen.

But if the game is on sale, buy it if you're looking for a simple short and sweet take on a horror.
If I were to rate this out of 10, I'd give it a 5/10.

reviewText:
The most obvious complaint you'll get is that the game is too short. You could speed run in an hour or so, or take some time to enjoy the ambience.  Monument Valley (mobile game) is the same kind of beast; short but very enjoyable.

To be honest the 3-d models come across a bit unpolished (specifically the mother), but once you are 1/3 of the way through you don't notice anymore because you are too distracted by the SUPURB audio.  Seriously this game's audio is on par if not better than Outlast in keeping you nervous about what's about to happen (wear headphones). Puzzle elements aren't too difficult and I feel like it was designed in the same spirit of Super Meat Boy in how it introduces a mechanic and then expands on it, slowly guiding you as needed until you understand all the options at your disposal.

There are some jump scares sure, good ones in fact, and it's not excessive and the times where you are hiding from [REDACTED] are suspenseful.  The ending was good simply for the fact that they didn't take the easy way out with the story. You may think you have it figured out as you go along looking at drawings thrown about but it's not quite what it seems.

I was a kickstarter backer, and I don't regret it, seeing how you can spend $20 on a few pizzas this is very much worth the price, and there has been DLC announced which I believe will be free.

I'd give it a 7/10

reviewText:
Great game. But way too short.

Graphics are fine. Could be a little better. But it's still nice to look at.
Sound is alright. Some cute sounds here and there. And the atmosphere sounds are done fairly decently.
Story is an interesting take on horrors. It's very simple though. Nothing fancy. Kind of leaves you with some questions.
Gameplay itself is simple but fun. Though very very easy.

But the killer of this game is the price and it's extremely short storyline. You can finish this within an hour to two hours with ease. There is no challenge and the scares are well... not so scary. They are quite simple and predictable. Nothing fancy. So chances are if you're used to horrors, you won't really get much of a scare out of this. The only thing I had was a few jump scares. But there was very little suspense for me.

There is not really any replayability either on this. The game had far more potential to really be a powerful game with a deep story, proper scares and indepth gameplay. But sadly this did not happen.

But if the game is on sale, buy it if you're looking for a simple short and sweet take on a horror.
If I were to rate this out of 10, I'd give it a 5/10.

reviewText: Vulnerability is a long forgotten element in what made video gaming horror such a powerful thing.  But Among The Sleep has gone to great lengths not to forget this. It casts you into the role of a toddler, turns out the lights, and asks you to explore the shadows.  Vulnerability is effortlessly achieved when the character you control can barely walk on its own. Wobbling along on uncertain feet leads your first person view to bobble from side to side as you advance. Keep it up for too long, and you‚Äôll fall onto your hands and knees where you‚Äôll crawl instead at a much brisker pace. Tilt your view enough to see yourself, and you glance tiny grasping hands, and a body clad in a dark blue onesie with a star and moon print. Pause the game, and the static options menu is brought up only after the infant has covered their eyes with their little hands. It‚Äôs occasionally adorable. It‚Äôs always, always nerve-racking. There‚Äôs something out there in the dark -- how are you supposed to fend it off?\n\nFull review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12295/miscellaneous/among-the-sleep/review.html

reviewText:
When I was very young and prone to getting seperated from my parents in department stores I would later have nightmares about hiding in the center of the circular clothing racks, peeking out from under heavy wool coats and suits while monsters sought my tender flesh in the darkness.

This is just one of the intense emotional experiences of this game which is painted from every spectrum of emotional palette you can imagine: from the rainbow joy of discovery and exploration as you search for your mother to the black depths of terror and loneliness.

This game is not only a masterpiece of survival horror but a poignant piece of storytelling at the same time.  It terrifies on a completely psychological level with a perfect counterpoint of harmonious safety and aesthetically amazing exploration as you get closer to your mother and the end of the tale.

This is one of the most intense five hours I've ever spent on a game title and everyone should experience this game no matter what genre of games you are into.

reviewText:
There is nothing scarier than being a toddler who's looking for their mum, while crawling through creepy environments that have something wicked lurking in every shadow.

It is not often that I find a horror game worthy to be standing tall beside great titles such as Amnesia and Slender, but Among the Sleep is definitely one of those horror games. While the game clearly reveals its Indie roots by having a playtime value of about two hours, depending on how much of a scaredy cat you are, it's dripping with a great concoction of creepy visuals, haunting sounds and eerie music. It has done what many so called horror titles of this day and age fail to do; frighten me. Among the Sleep shines in making you feel like the fragile little child you control, and it's just enough to make your skin crawl as you struggle to open doors and find elaborate ways to climb on top of a drawer.

Check it out when you've got the time and cash! This game is definitely worth your time if you're a fan of horror that has the potential to make you soil your pants.

reviewText:
I would like to start off by saying that I rarely play horror games.  Among the Sleep caught my attention by its promise of an emersive I rarely play horror games as I am a little bit of a wimp when it comes to being scared.  However, Among the Sleep caught my attention with its promise of an immersive world and a new perspective.  Both of which it delivered very well.  I started the game expecting to be scared out of my mind, but this game was very mild on the horror spectrum.  There was a small hand full of times that my heart raced and I jumped a little.  Very reminiscent of my childhood days when I remember being afraid to walk around the house in the dark because my imagination had already created all of the worst possible things that could be waiting to grab me.

The biggest complaint I read in reviews was that the game was too short.  And really it was, however I also don‚Äôt think it should have been much longer.  The puzzles were relatively simple.  I got lost a couple of times in areas that seemed a little circular and the right direction was hard to decipher.  Otherwise the game moved at a steady pace.

I‚Äôm glad I played this game and would recommend it to anyone looking for something to occupy a few hours of their time.  Seeing the world from the height of a 2 year old gave a fresh perspective and I believe the development and design of the game was very well done.

reviewText: Among the Sleep is a fairly unique experience as a game viewed through the eyes of a 2-year-old (no major spoilers ahead, don't worry). It oozes atmosphere akin to Amnesia and has the stylish flair of Psychonauts. I would re-tag this game primarily as an adventure story with horror elements as there aren't too many unsettling factors aside from a few jump scares and monsters. The world is like a childhood storybook and your guide is Teddy, a sentient stuffed bear whose eyes glow when he's squeezed (Glow Worm much?). I finished the game in 3 hours and my gaming laptop chug-chug-chugged along. There seem to be lag issues and when reduced to lower qualities some models and textures glitch and flicker. There are a few bugs, but nothing to complain greatly about though it is a bummer that immersion gets broken once in a while when immersion is the game's pride and joy. Among the Sleep is worth playing through, but there isn't much replay value unless you want to spend time playing with your toys. It's certainly a game to add to a horror fanatic's collection. I expect great things from Krillbite Studios in the future!

This is the first horror game I have played, so I don't have that many experience with horror games. But the unique concept that this game has to offer made me curious and decided to play it.

Normally in a game, we're given the abilities to survive against the antagonist of the game. But in this game, as a two year old, we don't have the capability to at least fight back against the antagonists. Without it, we can only do what two year olds can do to survive, run and hide. We don't have a sense of control of the antagonists.

An interesting plot twist is waiting at the end of this unique experience. This kind of unique concept has a lot of potentials to explore.

reviewText:
I'll let others review the scary aspect of this game. I wanna focus on the toddler simulation aspect.

Holy cow. I wish there was a way to just have a toddler simulator based on these mechanics. After I played through the actual storyline I went back and started over again and just played around in the playroom and was blown away by the attention to physics. Drag a stool across the wooden floor, it slides okay. Push it across carpet and you're in for a struggle. You can't lift a pillow above your head but you can toss an inflatable ball a few feet.

You can pick things up, put them down, open and close things, climb and even fall. There's no health bar so spills don't really matter. You wobble when you walk and make appropriate sounds as you move around. And it's interesting to see the world from the perspective of one so small (again). In all I would love to see more done with just the simulator side of things. It would be a riot to run around the house and interact with the environment without having to worry about the 'bad guys' getting you.

After a long hard week of adulting, sometimes I don't want my gaming to give me puzzles or enemies to deal with. I just want to unwind. but I'm not into the farming or app-type games. This is just my style! I'd love to see more walking simulators like this.

That said, the spooky aspect to this game and the storyline are both awesome. Sometimes though I couldn't help wondering if -I- was the monster. Something about all the crawling through vents and bookcases and scurrying under beds...

reviewText:
I just finished the game, let my emotional reaction fade away, and now I gotta say I love it. There are a few glitches still, and my game crashed making me replay the last chapter, but I didn't mind so much other than having to get through a few scary moments again.

Keep in mind I do not normally play horror games, I'm extremely skittish and jump scares always tend to get me. I thought the game was a good level of overall eerieness without being so scary I couldn't play. It's not going to scare horror veterans, but the story is more important in my eyes. The ending had me scared for the adorable little protagonist in more ways than one.

As far as length it's a short game. Took me about 4 hours including redoing that last chapter. Any more though would've been padding, as the game told it's story quite well in the time taken. There's not a ton of replay value as the emotional reaction is never the same as the first time, but I know a few people I'll be suggesting this too.

I did not see the ending coming. I had a similar idea to what happened, but was a bit off. The sound design was pretty good throughout, although if I play again I'll probably adjust the levels so some of the noises are a bit obnoxious after too long.

I'm looking forward to seeing more from this company, and have no regrets with getting this game.

reviewText:
[NO SPOILERS]

For the love of god, do not spend $20 on this game.

Visuals (8/10)
Sound (6/10)
Gameplay (4/10)
Storyline (5/10)
Replay value (none)

This one belongs in the horror genre as much as Goat Simulator. You get a few shock scares, but all in all it's a puzzle game with a dark setting. The terror vibe wears out about 30 mins in and never comes back. I'll admit that the idea of the main character being a 2-year old with their teddy interested me enough to buy the game and although I enjoyed some parts, I regret buying Among the Sleep.

One play-through is only between 2-3 hours; waaay too short for the price. The graphics lag a bit in certain areas but it's not too bad. The redeeming factor of this game are the visuals. Very well-done, except for the mom's face. Sounds are kind of repetitive, but nothing to get real mad about.

What I did get mad about was the fact that I paid $20 for a 3 hour game that doesn't get you on the edge of your seat. I was disappointed with this title, and wouldn't recommend it to anyone. How sad :(


------[SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT]-----




The play time is about 2-3 hours depending on how much you run/walk. Initially it's more intuitive to walk than run because you don't know what the game is all about. After about 30 minutes you realize there's no real backlash to being caught by the monster and you run through everything. This is where the game lost me.

First of all, it reveal what the monster looks like waaaay too early. In fact, they shouldn't have ever done that considering the short play time. after it's revealed you lose all sense of this game being the least bit frightening. Aside from a few instances where you actually have to hide from the monster to avoid the harsh penalty [sarcasm] of starting almost exactly where you were caught with no progress rewind, there's no real 'horror-value'. There is only 1 event where you have to consider not just plowing through the map. Bottles on top of blocks that summon the monster if they fall? Brilliant, I love it! Showing every bit of what happens during that scene in your teaser trailer? Moronic.

The end scene has a bit of redeming factors in that we're taken for a loop to find out our once loving mother is actually an abusive alcoholic stuggling with the idea of continuing on as a single parent. Lovely. That, combined with the recent dismemberment of best friend Teddy, we've basically witnessed the making of a potential psychopath. Maybe the sequel will have us mass murdering 1st graders! Buy this game if you have money to burn.

reviewText:
The demo was amazing, however the gameplay of the finished version barely expands on what the demo showed. What gameplay there was (about 1 1/2 hours) was really fun, and had a few interesting mechanics, however there were several bugs that ruined the gameplay a bit. The character developement of Teddy was a little sloppy in the way that he's introduced, but over the course of the game, he becomes a lovable character.

Things I liked:
The plot progression was really well done, and it had an interesting twist at the end.
The limitations of movement accurately represented what it would be like as a small child.
The bear-flashlight (Awwh!).
The non-violent terrifying monster and hide sequences.
The plot twist at the end.

Things I didn't like:
The extremely short gameplay.
The multiple bugs that ruined gameplay a bit.
The high cost for such little gameplay.
The somewhat repetitive ambience.

Overall, the game is a really fun experience, but not worth $20. The different sections each have their own unique ambiences and creepy layouts, and usually make you not want to leave any hidey-hole that you find. The gameplay is really short, and leaves you feeling like you bought an incomplete game. Teddy is a lovable character and a useful flashlight, and the movement is realistic, but the combination of bugs and short gameplay ruined the experience a little bit. If this game is ever $8 or lower, then it would definitely be worth the purchase!

reviewText:
It's a very simplistic puzzle game with a few jumpscares and some chasing sequences. I found myself jumping into the water out of boredom just to hear the sound of crunching bones (from what I assume was some water monster eating me), BEGGING for something to kill me to relieve the tedium of collecting items, using them to open a door, and continuing, while the ambience and lighting tried to convince me I was in some kind of danger, then 80% of the time it was just smoke and mirrors and I was completely aware of it.

I was SUPER amused by all the little details of being a baby. The cooing, the bear, and the pause screen is adorable - he holds his hands up and covers his eyes, like a kid would do when trying to hide from scary monsters - but all charm aside, I would NOT have bought this game knowing how short it is (for 20 dollars, no less) if I hadn't been suckered into thinking this was a bona fide horror game. It's a glorified puzzle game with some creepy theming, but Amnesia was both much more challenging and much more terrifying. This game borrows a lot from well-established series and just feels kind of cheap, and you can beat it in about an hour or two.

To be frank, there were some very creepy moments. When I was being chased by the darkness monsters, I felt like they were clearly gaining on me faster than I could crawl, so there was a nice helpless element to it like I expected to get snatched up RIGHT as I was about to make it to a a safe place. There are also ambiguous crayon drawings, which is usually a cliche in a horror game - children drawing crude depictions of murder or creepy ladies with long, black hair - but in this context it was pretty chilling on occasion. At one point I saw what looked like a tall dark figure holding up a stick-figure infant above its' open jaws, about to devour it. It's rare for anyone to address the murder of children/babies in games, so that's a unique theme that gives it that extra Ugh
