reviewText:
Among the Sleep is really something. It's such a unique game and a fresh and new take into horror - something original that hasn't been done before. The story and game are really short, but the story-telling is incredible and beautiful and so well done.

You play the protagonist role of a 2 year old toddler, you're movement is slow and sluggish, you can't travel anywhere too fast or you'll fall over, but crawling around is great because you're used to that! You can interact with the world around you by pushing buttons, picking things up, turning them around and looking at them and doing other things as you explore the world around you and develop. However, this is where the story telling begins. You experience the story in such a parculiar yet fascinating perspective of the young and still developing mind of this 2 year old. So things aren't as they seem, things are confusing and odd, but a key piece of detail I love the developers for is simple yet so effective.

The world around you is new and scary.

There's not a great deal I can tell you without spoiling the game and I don't intend to as it is an experience that is satisfying to indulge into.

Is this game worth buying? Yes, but be sure to pick it up on a sale as it is REALLY short. You can get through the game and its DLC in a matter of a couple of hours, but don't let that put you off, it is a truly interesting and amazing game that almost brought a tear to my eye when I understood the story behind it.

I rate this game a strong 8.9/10
I recommend this game to horror go-getters, people who want an interesting short story to experience and anyone who can appreciate a new take on this genre.

reviewText: So here's what I felt about the story and atmosphere of this game in particular hopefully without spoiling anything:\n\nAt first it didn't make too much sense and I felt as if it were just going to throw me, a two year old man, into a dark helpless environment where everything was out to kill me. However it only did part of that. The atmosphere was very well constructed to resemble what a two year old could possibly be taking in if it were scared of something. Everything that was around me that I would look to for direction and expected to be able to read was surprisingly to me, not in English. It was symbols and characters that made me think that it was the doing of aliens. However, looking back on it after completing the game, and realizing the message of the game, it wasn't in English because I was just a two year old. That struck me as interesting. Another thing on the topic of me being scared ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•less looking to the environment for direction is that there were drawings. In all the little nooks and cranny's that I would crawl to to hide from whatever I thought was chasing me had a little drawing of what a child would interpret towards whatever the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• was going down. That was another thing that I was impressed with. Now, when it comes to scary ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I do not like to be a part of it. Sure I'll watch it, but ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• everything about participating in it and leading the charge. But this game really got me hooked. I was a little sad but relieved that it was so short, but I feel like they timed everything just perfectly. And the noises... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• those noises. But back to the point here. The game didn't focus on jump-scaring a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, but instead it focused on timing events just right to where the smallest mistake you make would scare the junk out of you. It really made you pay attention to what you were doing, where you were crawling/walking/bumping into, and why you were seeing the things you were. Unlike Amnesia, it really plays with more emotions than just fear. It gives you that feeling of Why" rather than "Okay

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a first-person, atmospheric horror adventure game for the perspective of a 2-year old child. Everything is huge. Crawling and staggered walking are integral to how you move around. Your childlike imagination is incredibly active. Norwegian developer, Krillbite Studio, have done an amazing job at placing you in the onesie of a toddler and then subsequently placing you in a night where everything is going bump.

Among the Sleep uses a whole arsenal of horror techniques to keep you sweating and on the edge of your seat. As I mentioned, it is an atmospheric horror game. A dark house on a stormy night full of creaks, with the faint noise of a plate breaking or muffled voices can be terrifying. Especially at first when you‚Äôre wandering through the house as doors creak open behind you, the sound of heavy footsteps echo throughout the house, and there are shadows framing what I assumed at the time were burly, axe-wielding convicts. I would advise playing the game slightly brighter than recommended setting. Not because I‚Äôm a coward, but more because the recommended gamma setting was too dark and I couldn‚Äôt actually see what I was doing. Though the game does provides a solution to this. There is a ‚ÄúHug Teddy‚Äù button which causes Teddy to light up, softly illuminating the darkness around you.

While I‚Äôm generally not a huge fan of horror games due to being a bit flighty and preferring games that empower. But I still enjoyed the horror in Among the Sleep academically. Having you play a toddler was an interesting game elements that I‚Äôve never seen it before and thoroughly enjoyed. The game might seem steep in price for a 5-6 hour game, but you pay more for a 2 hour movie, and a lot more for games that that far less unique and well-thought out.

For full review, visit
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/07/11/among-the-sleep/

reviewText: This was... kind of disappointing. Now, that's not to say I didn't have fun with the game. There is a lot of good stuff to it. However, Among the Sleep is painfully short at only two hours long, and is really more of a 'roadtrip' game, where you look at stuff and experience stuff on a very linear path that, once experienced, really doesn't have anything else to offer. Furthermore, the biggest issue I came across was the monster(s). They were too easy to hide from, and I'll be honest, they really aren't all that threatening when you can just dive into a closet or under a table and know they won't try to look for you. One last big complaint I have is this: stop with the static-y screen when looking at monsters developers! Seriously, whenever you look at a monster the screen erupts into a static filled mess, and rather than scare me, it just irritated me and distracted me from the game. The thing that should be scary about an unknown creature is the very presence of an unknown creature. If the static eruption didn't happen, I probably would feel more of a threat, because the actual creatures and their designs, while simplistic, do in fact have a bigger than life feel when seen through the eyes of the toddler you play as. So Krillbite, in your next game, stop with the static thing. If you want to do something like that again however, try to be slightly more subtle about it, rather than have the screen scream 'YOU ARE FRIGHTENED NOW! OOOOHHH SO SPOOKY!' Stop it. No, I'm not scared, I'm annoyed.\nNow, despite ripping into some of the more major problems, I still recommend this game. Why? Because it is absolutely gorgeous. The aesthetic of the game is incredible, being colorful, but still very dark and creepy, and while the actual graphics of the game aren't the best, they still lend to alter the perceptions you ight have of the world. At the beginning, I found my own mind playing tricks on me, making me think there were thing in places where there was nothing, much like a child would. I absolutely loved that the enviornment of the game could do that on its own, even more so than any of the monsters. The mechanics also lend themselves well to the ideas of the game. You have on your journey a teddy bear that you can hug for comfort, and teddy then acts as a light source to help you see the path you need to go down. When pausing, the toddler covers his face with his hands to hide from the scary things, again bringing in the feeling that this is a young child in a big threatening world that he doesn't understand. To open doors, you need to get chairs to reach the knob, and you move faster crawling that you do walking.\nSo, overall, I think that this game does have some good things to offer, and as Krillbite's first game, I think they did a decent job. However, I don't recommend dropping twenty dollars on this game. Wait for the price to drop, and/or wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Are you searching for a rather unique type of horror experience? Has your thirst for psychological torment this year not been quenched yet? Do you crave to relive old childhood nightmares? Then Among The Sleep might be for you...

This delightfully terrifying experience grants gamers the opportunity to explore a creepy Silent Hill-esque world of terror through the eyes of a toddler. That premise alone should capture anyone's curiosity. For what does a helpless baby represent the most? Exactly... Helplessness. You are no soldier, no athletic investigator - just a baby in the land of giants. One that can barely walk on two feet. You don't get to see that type of scenario every day. But what can be said about the game itself?

Both music and sounds, arguably the most important parts of any horror game, do not disappoint. You'll often be looking over your shoulder to check whether that ominous noise in the distance was really just part of the ambiance or instead a sinister monster stalking you. Among The Sleep definitely plays it's cards well, and spends a good quarter of it's length on excellent build-up to the main events. Especially the first big area, a forested house located within a foggy swamp, managed to freak me out again and again. I'd not want to return there anytime soon, that's for sure.

In terms of gameplay you'll be collecting stuff in order to access new places. A lot of stuff. Perhaps too much stuff? Eh, it didn't bother me in all honesty. The environments are beautifully designed, and keep things interesting enough to overshadow the simplistic puzzles. I swear to god though... That evil forest. Or the playground before it. The atmosphere oozes greatness around every corner. You'll never know what to expect next. Better grow used to being all alone, for your only companion" happens to be a teddy bear - one who also serves as a sort of light source if hugged tightly. How charming. Well

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is really something. It's such a unique game and a fresh and new take into horror - something original that hasn't been done before. The story and game are really short, but the story-telling is incredible and beautiful and so well done.

You play the protagonist role of a 2 year old toddler, you're movement is slow and sluggish, you can't travel anywhere too fast or you'll fall over, but crawling around is great because you're used to that! You can interact with the world around you by pushing buttons, picking things up, turning them around and looking at them and doing other things as you explore the world around you and develop. However, this is where the story telling begins. You experience the story in such a parculiar yet fascinating perspective of the young and still developing mind of this 2 year old. So things aren't as they seem, things are confusing and odd, but a key piece of detail I love the developers for is simple yet so effective.

The world around you is new and scary.

There's not a great deal I can tell you without spoiling the game and I don't intend to as it is an experience that is satisfying to indulge into.

Is this game worth buying? Yes, but be sure to pick it up on a sale as it is REALLY short. You can get through the game and its DLC in a matter of a couple of hours, but don't let that put you off, it is a truly interesting and amazing game that almost brought a tear to my eye when I understood the story behind it.

I rate this game a strong 8.9/10
I recommend this game to horror go-getters, people who want an interesting short story to experience and anyone who can appreciate a new take on this genre.

Among The Sleep is a stellar little interactive adventure with some light horror elements and some good-looking surreal imagery. You play as a toddler of unspecified gender who wakes up one night to find his mother and his trusty teddy bear missing. You have to navigate the intricacies of the dream world, solving puzzles, finding keys, and avoiding a horrible monster that's totally not meant to be symbolic of anything, honest.

It's really short; I wouldn't recommend buying it at the current price, but at a price drop, it's definitely a pleasant interactive experience and the light horor elements are done really well. It's also very similar to Amnesia and other games in that genre, so if you're not into the whole First Person Horror Adventure thing, I'd probably give this pass.

If you played Amnesia, and felt it would be better if you were 4 feet shorter and had a best friend Teddy Bear, Among The Sleep is for you.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a psychological adventure game where you are put in the shoes (so to speak) of a toddler while he tries to find her missing mother during nighttime with the help of his fellow, rather talkative teddy bear companion.
You navigate the various environments of the game from the very eyes of the toddler: you are mainly tasked to overcome various obstacles along your path (by either crowling, climbing or rarely use some items you collected and put in an inventory) and advance further through the chapters. You can also hug Teddy to illuminate your surrondings (even if, sadly, this feature isn't brought up as much as one would expect).
While many believe this is a full-fledged horror game, Among the Sleep is more interested into make you see how disturbing reality can be when saw from a toddler's point of view and how it twists everything it touches. Therefore, don't expect any jump scare or chases: the game is very tense and will sometime try to screw with you, but that's pretty much about it.
The graphics are stylized enough, with their strongest suit being the peculiar and warped level design. The same cannot be said for other models in the game, but they don't tend to stand out that much.
The only DLC for the game, Prologue, is unfortunately very short, clocking around half an hour (that is, if you take your sweet time) and not adding everything worthwhile to the formula you've already experienced in the main game. This is especially annoying because the main story isn't that long either (clocking around three or four hours).
If you love that kind of games that can offer you an unique and artistic" experience without being that keen on a superb gameplay
date: Among the Sleep could be yet another game to add to your Steam library"

reviewText:
I really like this game a lot--it's short, sad, and sweet. What makes it unique is the perspective; it's a first person perspective horror game where you play as a 2-year-old toddler. The game really makes you see the world through the imagination and fears of a little child. The visual design of the game succeeds in making benign everyday objects look menacing when in the dark. Is that some sort of monster standing there watching you? Or is it simply a coat on a coat rack with some boots sticking out the bottom of it? Even your own toys can sometimes seem unsettling. I liked how, whenever you see written text in the game, like in an open book, for example, it looks like gibberish, since your character can't read. Sound effects are used effectively at the right times to evoke a sense of dread and fear.

In my opinion, the star of the show here is Teddy, your imaginary friend teddy bear who seems alive and who is with you you traverse the dark, avoiding a monster and looking for your missing mother. Teddy is an ambiguous character; cute n' creepy. Is he there to help you or is he not to be trusted? He is well voice-acted, but there are long sections of the game where you almost forget he is with you because he doesn't have much to say. I realize this is under the pretense that you both have to be quite so as not to alert the monster to your presence, but I just feel like Teddy could have been used more in some of the middle sections of the game.

I'm not going lie, this game can really get you into the mindset of a small child and I did find myself weeping after the climax and at the end. The game can be scary, but there's no blood and guts or anything. But be aware that the game delves into issues that kids shouldn't have to face, but sometimes do. The evidence to me that this game successfully told a story with some emotional impact was the fact that it gave me the feels even though I had a pretty stable and happy childhood.

reviewText:
I really like this game a lot--it's short, sad, and sweet. What makes it unique is the perspective; it's a first person perspective horror game where you play as a 2-year-old toddler. The game really makes you see the world through the imagination and fears of a little child. The visual design of the game succeeds in making benign everyday objects look menacing when in the dark. Is that some sort of monster standing there watching you? Or is it simply a coat on a coat rack with some boots sticking out the bottom of it? Even your own toys can sometimes seem unsettling. I liked how, whenever you see written text in the game, like in an open book, for example, it looks like gibberish, since your character can't read. Sound effects are used effectively at the right times to evoke a sense of dread and fear.

In my opinion, the star of the show here is Teddy, your imaginary friend teddy bear who seems alive and who is with you you traverse the dark, avoiding a monster and looking for your missing mother. Teddy is an ambiguous character; cute n' creepy. Is he there to help you or is he not to be trusted? He is well voice-acted, but there are long sections of the game where you almost forget he is with you because he doesn't have much to say. I realize this is under the pretense that you both have to be quite so as not to alert the monster to your presence, but I just feel like Teddy could have been used more in some of the middle sections of the game.

I'm not going lie, this game can really get you into the mindset of a small child and I did find myself weeping after the climax and at the end. The game can be scary, but there's no blood and guts or anything. But be aware that the game delves into issues that kids shouldn't have to face, but sometimes do. The evidence to me that this game successfully told a story with some emotional impact was the fact that it gave me the feels even though I had a pretty stable and happy childhood.

reviewText:
It‚Äôs hard to know how big an effect a parent‚Äôs actions can have on children, until certain mannerisms start to materialise in that child‚Äôs behaviour. In Among the Sleep, you‚Äôll be confronted by such scenes that might bring a tear to the eye of parents who play through. I‚Äôm not a parent myself, but at the end I couldn‚Äôt help staring at the screen in bewilderment of what I had just played through. Read more in our Among the Sleep review below.

Having just finished watching the film ‚ÄúRoom‚Äù, I was reminded just how much an adult‚Äôs behaviour can impact the lives of their children. Among the Sleep touches on quite a lot of issues that parents face, but more importantly, it takes you on a two-year old toddlers journey through a world of imagination that depicts just how different a child‚Äôs perception of their surroundings is.

There is so much about Among the Sleep‚Äôs story that I‚Äôd love to talk about, but unfortunately that would involve spoiling the majority of the game. I‚Äôm going to do my best to touch upon certain aspects without potentially ruining the experience of those who are yet to play it.

Happy Birthday
The beginning of Among the Sleep starts with the toddling protagonist downing a glass of drink. Because of the way you are first seeing the world through the rounded walls of a drinking glass, my first impression was that I might be witnessing a birth scene. But as I moved my mouse around, more and more of the world became visible. Eventually I was left looking at the beaming face of the toddler‚Äôs mother. It was the two-year old‚Äôs birthday and the mother was preparing a cake.

As you wait for the cake to be presented to you, you‚Äôre given the opportunity to look around the kitchen, and even play with an abacus. Finally mother comes back with the cake and cuts a slice for mister toddler to eat. Unfortunately, before we got to sink our teeth into this tasty looking cake, we were interrupted by a knock at the door of the toddler‚Äôs house.

Here‚Äôs where the strangeness begins. Distortion lines start to appear around everything and the sound becomes muted. A growing feeling of unease pierces the atmosphere. Just as you‚Äôre starting to think you‚Äôve fallen into a scene from Paranormal Activity, the distortion dissipates when you hear the mother shout ‚ÄúNO!‚Äù, and slam the door.

Back she comes with a present in her hands and a face conveniently disguised with a big smile. But before you‚Äôre allowed to open it, she picks you up and takes you and the present upstairs. You get placed in a playpen and the present is set down upon a chest of drawers. When the mother leaves the room, you gain control of the toddler.

The usual ‚ÄòWASD‚Äô keys control your movement while the mouse is used to look around. Also, ‚Äòleft-click‚Äô allows you to interact with objects. Obviously toddlers aren‚Äôt known for their jumping prowess, so instead of jump, the ‚Äòspace-bar‚Äô allows you climb onto platforms such as chairs and open drawers. Holding ‚Äòshift‚Äô lets you sprint for a short period of time, but instead of being presented with a stamina gauge, you‚Äôll simply fall over when you can no longer keep up the pace. The ‚Äòcontrol‚Äô key drops you to the floor and allows you to crawl through narrow nooks and crannies.

Eventually you come across Teddy. A loveable soft toy who accompanies you on your adventure. In the toddler‚Äôs mind, Teddy can talk, and informs you that by pressing ‚ÄòF‚Äô to cuddle him, you‚Äôll feel safer. What he really means is that he‚Äôll light up and allow you to see in really dark places. To be honest, I was constantly pressing ‚ÄòF‚Äô because it gets quite creepy in the dark‚Ä¶ Not only is Teddy a provider of light, but he also acts as a guide to the toddler.

Playing Around
The gameplay in Among the Sleep mainly consists of solving puzzles. Each puzzle rewards you with a memory that‚Äôs required for progressing to the next area of the game. The puzzles are relatively simple and won‚Äôt require a lot of thinking to solve, but the journey involved in solving each puzzle takes you through some incredibly imaginative environments; from dark, creepy playgrounds, to mazes of bookshelves haunted by a tall, crazy-haired, lurching monster.

Speaking of monsters, you‚Äôre not going to find as many of them out in the dark as you believed you would as a child. However, in later areas of the game, the tall monsters will appear more frequently. If they catch you, you‚Äôll be in trouble and have to start again from a previous checkpoint. Thankfully the checkpoints come around often, and you won‚Äôt be replaying certain parts of puzzles over and over.

Among the Sleep incorporates a great physics engine that allows you to open drawers, cupboards, fridges and interact with pretty much anything you can see. Some puzzles and achievements require you to pick up certain items and throw them. This gives things an extra injection of realism and also lengthens the overall gameplay experience.

An extra little incentive when playing Among the Sleep are the many toddler-like drawings scattered around each area. The drawings depict some scenes we can only imagine are events the toddler has lived through.

All throughout Among the Sleep, you‚Äôll be followed by a feeling of unease. Teddy will whisper to you that things look dangerous and you should be careful. Creepy sounds and crescendos in the music add a feeling of panic to your journey, and when you first encounter the creepy, tall, crazy-haired monster, you‚Äôll be looking over your shoulder every time you hear something out of the ordinary.

Aesthetic Charm
From the moment you are taken upstairs and witness the introduction credits apparate before your eyes in the form of glowing lights, you can tell that you‚Äôre in for a visual treat. The graphics have a cartoony feel to them, resembling something you might see in a Pixar film. Everything in the real world is drawn with such bright, vivid colours. Each colour stands out the way you‚Äôd imagine a toddler to see them. In contrast, the imaginary world is dark, full of shadows and incorporates creepy distorted shapes to the overall design of things.

Playing as a toddler, you would expect their movement to be quite wobbly and Krillbite Studios certainly deliver in terms of wobbliness. It definitely injects an extra bit of realism to the character you are playing. Otherwise it might just feel like you‚Äôre playing as any FPS character in an overgrown world.

The soundtrack is eery and coats everything with an unnerving sheen. Sounds and effects raise goosebumps on your skin, especially when the monsters commence their pursuit of your tiny form.

Final Thoughts
Among the Sleep is truly a masterpiece and tells a story we‚Äôre all too familiar with. This could be confronting to some, but the way it plays out through the eyes and imagination of a toddler, portrays it in a different light. Those of you who aren‚Äôt parents might stop and reflect on the adventure you‚Äôve just played through. Parents might shed a tear or go and give an extra hug to their children.

The entire game is so smooth to play, and although it only lasts for around three hours, you‚Äôll feel like those three hours just flew by. Krillbite Studios have added Steam achievements to the game, so there‚Äôs a bit of replayability in terms of collecting everything and unlocking each achievement.

If you‚Äôre looking for a game that relies more on telling a rich story rather than throwing you deep into an action-packed shootout, Among the Sleep will not disappoint. It‚Äôs story will leave you speechless but you won‚Äôt be able to help yourself from wanting more.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is both beautiful and tragic at the same time.

The story unfolds in such a way that it leaves room for your imagination to run wild as you explore creatively designed areas, solve fun interactive puzzles, and hide from the monsters under your bed.

I was very impressed with the controls and the detail put into the game, from the cute pajamas right down to the stitching in the rug that you crawl across. Tons of items are intractable and it is surprisingly easy to lose yourself in simple things like stacking blocks or piling toys into chests.

The monsters in the game are unique and tie very well in to the story ‚Äì no spoilers, you need to play to the end! There are several moments in the game where the monsters can come after you, but if you are patient and hide well then they can be avoided to some extent.

My overall score for the game: 10/10. I really enjoyed this game, I even came back and played it again for the achievements and the prologue. The story is incredibly touching and will leave you with some pretty heavy emotions by the time you reach the end. Among the Sleep is a gem, don‚Äôt miss out on this one!

reviewText:
I bought this game shortly after spotting a post by someone who stated that they were extremely moved by this game and could personally relate to it as they were currently going through similar circumstances. Not realizing that this game 'could' be based on a true story I decided to give it a gander.

Let me first start off with saying that if you are able to relate to the things this kid goes through, then I feel extremely sorry for you, knowing that your just a couple of steps away from blending in with the Addams family. I would also like to state that I will try my hardest not to ruin any surprises in this game as the game has very 'little' to 'no' replay-ability value.

After playing most games I ask myself, 'Am i a better person now for having played it?', more often than not the answer is 'no!' In fact some times its even 'I am worse for having played it'. Not so with this game. In fact I left the game having a better appreciation for certain things than when I entered into it. Here's the beauty of the game and where the game shines. Basically your paying for the experience you get from having played this game and it's concept of making you view life from another perspective, that being said ... a 2 yr old.

Here's where I began to appreciate things more. I began to appreciate how dangerous life is for a 2 yr old, a small puddle is something I can potentially drown in and a drawer in the kitchen is a ladder I can use to get to that toaster which could easily burn my face off.

That being said, the main enemy in the game is a handful of monsters and the main one being a cross breed between a clump of seaweed, a Triffid and a stick of Broccoli drawn by Timothy Burton. The game has nothing to do with the supernatural, however you do know that with the need of avoiding monsters and finding memories, something must be wrong somewhere.

The biggest downfall to the game is the controls, they were hardly precise and often felt awkward. For instance the hand icon to show you could interact with an object often appeared even if you were not close enough to 'really' interact with it and the designated controls on a controller for walk or crawl are the same ones needed to rotate handles. Hence instead of rotating you often would spend five minutes not being able to make up your mind if you wanted to walk or crawl on a handle. Granted you can customize controls, but i'm lazy and my idea of going outside is to turn on supermario 64 and get my character to look up into the nice blue sky. Also with the monsters always snapping at your baby feet, every millisecond reaction counts and if an icon appears to say you can interact with something, but you really can't because your not close enough, well it just heightens a players frustration level as they're spine begins to tickle the tonsils of the 'satanic evil brocolli'.

There are a couple of ways to avoid the monsters. 1) Hide under beds or in confined cupboards 2) Hug teddy so hard you snap it's neck 3) Soil your pants and hopefully the smell will send the monster away. Unfortunately options like lay a couple proximity mines down are not in the game.

The developers have really gone into quite extensive detail with the game which often gets missed by the players. For instance the mother has a pale skin impression on one of her fingers where a wedding ring would have been. All the books and covers in the game seem to have Japanese writing on them, this is because to a 2 yr old everything would look Japanese would it not?

I would also like to point out that the developers have a 'credit fetish'. Seriously! The longest credits I have ever seen in a game. After the game finished I felt sorry and took my mum out to lunch, when we got back the credits were still rolling. The best part is, I later discovered that those credits were just a prequel to the real credits. After finishing the game you get to play some DLC and then treated to even more credits. Seriously the credits are so long that even the seasons change and winter steps in.

The game will take you 5 hrs at the max. Most of that will be spent watching credits. There are very few games in the market which force you to think in the shoes of someone else and maybe we need more games like this so that we become more conscientious, tolerant and sympathetic . I really do recommend the game, it's worth the experience, but that experience is not worth $20.00 which is the normal price. Wait for it to go on sale. By the way my mum tried to make me eat broccoli soup once and it did feel a lot like what was going on in the swamp in this game. So yes you could say it's based on a true story...Addams family here I come!

reviewText:
Among the Sleep proves that even indie devs are capable of hyping up a two hour walking simulation with poor sound and barely any scares. Perhaps you all saw that Kickstarter video where it seemed like a stealth game with high amounts of interactivity in its environment with a dense sense of climbable objects and places to hide? Well, guess what. It's not.

In fact, nothing is particularly done well here. Any horror" done in this game consists of only 10 mins of game time hiding from a swamp monster and a coat. Which was all done better in Penumbra and Amnesia anyway. Because even IN THIS GAME any sense of challenge flies out the window when you even the game over screen and are sent RIGHT BACK to a checkpoint with all progress still in. As in any items you got or objects moved etc. are still in the same place. There's no real puzzles. Not a single moment that sticks out. Everything was already done BETTER in other horror games. Even the innovation of being a two year old child falls flat on its face with terrible execution.

The sound effects are particularly dreadful. The quality ranges from well done to something from a DOS game. You'll get random whistle noises that cut off abruptly. Monster sound effects that sound like they came out of a really bad TMNT cartoon

and even no sound effects at all! REALLY! You can drop soap and you won't even hear a single thud!

As far as the story goes. It's the bare ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minimum for being "subtle". A child is being taken away from a drunk parent? reviewText:
So I just finished Among the Sleep, and I have to say it's one of the best explorational games I've ever played. To call it a horror is up to the player. Since there's a flowing narrative and not many survival elements, I think calling it a psychological drama would be more fitting.

When I came into the game I was pleasantly surprised at how much detail had gone into the world (after my controls decided to work), and really enjoyed the cartoonish art style. The character models could have been better but that's a minor nitpick.

Something else I noticed was the lack of deep sentiment in the early stages, and felt somewhat let down. However upon completing the game I realised what this all amassed to and why it seemed so by-the-books. I won't spoil anything but the moments leading up to the game's incredible ending are genuinely enthralling and some of the best I've ever experienced in gaming.

I think the game's ~2 hour length is perfect, as it allows for an incredibly streamlined experience. None of the game feels like filler. I am however disappointed at the slightly disgusting price of ¬£15. Yes, it is an incredible experience, but for 2 hours of gameplay I would never pay more than maybe ¬£8. Of course I made an exception for this as I've been waiting a long time for its release.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a PewDiePie-esque jumpscare fest then I really couldn't recommend this game to you. This game's horror comes from its subject matter and subtlely disturbing imagery. If you're a big fan of explorational games (Dear Esther, Amnesia: AMFP) then I highly recommend it, although I'd wait for a steam sale if I were you.

Graphics: 8/10 (Incredible art style let down by occasional bugs and performance issues)
Sound: 7/10 (Fittingly cheesy voice acting, and good ambient effects, however playing through I can see they missed a few solid opportunities for a good audio scare)
Gameplay: 9/10 (If you like explorational games then this is basically flawless as far as walking around goes. If you don't, its minimalistic mechanics may leave you bored)

Overall: 8/10

reviewText:
No spoilers to follow:

I have a difficult time recommending this game.  I will break it down into the things it does well and things it missed this mark on.

Pros:
The gameplay design is great.  You are faster while crawling, but are also at certain disadvantages for doing so.
The design of the environments is also well done which includes sound design!  The locations felt important and palpable.

Cons:
I have to mention length first.  It takes under three hours to beat, and while that alone does not make me hesitant to recommend the game, it does not help.
The story is full of foreshadowing which is good, but does so in a way that makes everything incredibly predictable.  The story  exists only to allow for the game to take place.
The scariness of the game is incredibly subjective, but I did not feel scared with the exception of one area of the game.  I will not spoil what makes me say this because that would ruin the fear that this game attempts to make you feel.  If you are observant, you will not be scared.


I played this game without an Occulus Rift which may be part of my lack of enthusiasm, but it does seem more like a tech demo for this device in its length and environments.  When the price drops on it, it may be worth it.  Twenty dollars seems high for a couple hours of scenery.

I also want to point out that the demo includes the best portion of the game since it occurs before the supernatural/dreamy location.  While some may appreciate the supernatural areas more so (and I agree that it allows for the game to become less predictable as it deviates from reality), I felt that it loses a large part of the empathy required to feel fear.

reviewText:
Another in the long line of indie horror games that never gets going, has an interesting concept that's quickly abandoned with left-field developments, all filled out with a clich√©d and predictable plot.

For the horror aspect, well it's best to say: even I wasn't scared by this game. I don't play many horror games, I'm easily scared by their shenanigans, but this one never really tried. It was certainly unsettling, but that's only down to you and how long it takes you to realise you can run around and make as much noise as you like when no demons come out to get you.

The concept seemed to be that you're roaming a hunted house or being attacked by demons, but with the killer twist that you're just a baby. This concept is explored for all of 20 minutes, after which you enter alternate worlds (the classic MC Escher-inspired linear platforming, toddler style). It doesn't help that you'll likely guess the ending and major plot points in the first 10 minutes. The characters say or do a couple of things at the start which appear to be hinting and foreshadowing, only for it to turn out they were just saying random crap you shouldn't have analysed.

This feels like a 3-hour concept video or game a developer would show publishers to get them to invest and publish a hypothetical full game. It's tempting to recommend this just for the potential it has even though it never used it. Instead it's another game that's best right at the start, then they go I guess we better put some generic gameplay crap in there so it's a game" and it's done.

P.S. It should also be noted that this is a Kickstarter game
date: and the backers who donated $150+ and qualified for rewards haven't received them. Another reason to not recommend this game."

reviewText:
This is a strange title. First off, the asking price (20$) is entirely too high. As a group, we tried twice to get into this, and just couldn't. Its an interesting idea, but in the end it can be boiled down to basically a walking simulator where you 'find the key' and 'find the door' deal.

Pros:
+Fresh idea
+Makes you feel like a small child
+Graphics are decent

Cons:
-Waaayyyyy too high of an asking price
-The game takes some seriously weird turns. I thought the whole game took place in the house, but it doesn't. You go down like this garbage shoot and enter another world, which is really strange, and I didn't like it.
-Basis of the gameplay is too simple. You basically just walk through the levels trying to open doors and trigger events. Its not terrible - its just bland and has been done a million times before. At this point (and for this price) I would have liked to see some novelty. Something fresh.
-While the graphics are nice, there is some parts that odd. Maybe they were done because you are a small child, but I don't think so. Like as an example, you walk by a couch that is entirely too big in comparison to the rest of the room (lamp, coffee table, etc.). It just felt flawed. Or shoes that seemed too big. If it was for the child experience, fine, but I don't think that is the case.

I would definately pass on this one. There are other similiar games that are better (and far cheaper). I paid 10 bucks and have buyers remorse.

reviewText:
If you enjoy stories where the plot isn't spoon fed to you, then this can be a great game. It's interesting to draw parelles and understand what the meaning of everything in the game is. As you play you can see how a toddler might see his world in the way that this one does. Things that aren't really dangerous can seem very scary to a child not old enough to understand what's what.

That said, the game is short, but maybe that's for the better. The gameplay itself does not stand on its own apart from the story, and I found it to start becoming tedious towards the end. I got the game (and others) for $5 from Humble Bundle, and I think it was well worth that purchase, though I don't think I'd want to pay much more than that.

All in all, a good way to burn 2 or 3 hours in a lazy afternoon.

reviewText:
[MILD SPOILERS]

Great ideas executed fairly poorly. The first 20 minutes are really good and drew me into the game completely. The intro with your mother, the teddy and the lead-in to the wardrobe world were great.

However, finicky climbing, not being sure if I can fit under things and ultimately not really being able to decipher the rules of the scares make the game a bit of a trudge. It gets really repetitive, even in the short period of time you actually have with the game. The story unfolds itself well and you end up having a good sense of what it has been trying to convey to you, but ends by just slapping you with it, just in case you hadn't figured it out on your own yet.

It started you off with something great and ultimately goes nowhere with it. The DLC is very much the same, it gives you something really interesting, gets repetitive and goes nowhere.

I wouldn't recommend this at its base price, it's far too short for that. Pick it up on sale if you're curious or give it a miss completely, I'm pretty indifferent to the game.

reviewText:
GREAT GAME, GET IT WHEN THERE IS A SALE!!!

Pros:
+Original player perspective
+Charming companion
+Manageable puzzles
+Meaningful story
+Voice acting
+Stayed away from silly jumpscares

Cons:
-Monster could be more threatening
-Scenery
-Price tag

I went into this game 'blind'. I had not watched any of the trailers or played the demo of this game, and I was pleasantly suprised by the origininality of the idea. Playing as a child really changed the dynamics of the player character. It was fun to crawl and solve simple puzzles like moving furniture to reach a doorknob, tasks that we often overlook as adults. Teddy, your stuffed animal friend, was a great companion. The story was meaningful, and the storytelling was well done (although the last scene kind of throws the mystery in your face, should have kept it ambiguous) The ending could be solved quickly, if you are brave enough to explore, ;) but still did not detract from the terror.

On the note of criticism, I found it was too easy to avoid the monster, Among the Sleep made it too obvious when the monster was near and gave you ample time to escape. While it wasn't reaally a bad thing, I would have liked to have felt more threatened. I liked the level design but a lot of the scenery got recycled as the game progressed. Like most horror games, Among the Sleep is really linear, limited opportunities to explore.

The voice acting was great! Nice job! I especially enjoyed the sounds the baby would make. If you fell from high up it would grunt, when near the monster it would breath heavily, and when running away in some moments the baby would squeal with terror. This really helped me sympathize with this poor child and I wish they had included more noises from the baby.

While it is from the perspective of a baby, the monster encounters felt all too familiar to other horror games. The idea of playing as a baby is so original, I just wish they would have expanded it to the monster encounters and tried something new. Thankfully, there is very little use of cheap jump scares.

For the time to play this game (2 hrs) the price tag is WAY TOO HIGH. My gosh... 20 dollars... I'm happy to support the developers and I am also a huge fan of horror, but I would highly recommend waiting to get this game on sale.

reviewText:
SPOILERS FOLLOW


the atmosphere in this game is top notch. amazing sound track, visuals, and puzzles that all inspire feelings of suspense and terror. A frightening and compelling nightmare world, made all the moreso by the fact that you play a two year old child.

that said, I felt like the twist in the end wasn't well realized. I was sure that things were going a certain way because, in my view, the entire game was setting you up to believe in a certain scenario. when it turned out otherwise it didn't have the impact it could have, because there is exactly zero foreshadowing in the beginning of the game. all of the foreshadowing portends the scenario I thought was going to take place, but didn't. frankly sometimes I think games nowadays try to shoe horn these twists in because it's the thing to do, but (and I felt this a little with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter) it would have been just as good if not better if played straight.

Some gameplay quibbles include how damn difficult it is to turn anything with the mouse.

the atmosphere in this game is top notch. amazing sound track, visuals, and puzzles that all inspire feelings of suspense and terror. A frightening and compelling nightmare world, made all the moreso by the fact that you play a two year old child.

that said, I felt like the twist in the end wasn't well realized. Some gameplay quibbles include how damn difficult it is to turn anything with the mouse.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is short, but sweet. It's an interesting experience, absolutely dripping with atmosphere. Playing as a toddler in a scary world, and knowing you're defenseless, is a very eye-opening and unique experience. All of this is brought together to tell an interesting and troubling story from the eyes of someone who doesn't understand the world.I'm not typically a fan of horror games, but this one just seemed so unique that I had to Kickstart it, and the final product does not disappoint.

A few warnings to make sure you know what you're buying:

1. Among the Sleep is really short - you can finish it and get 100% achievements in less than three hours, and it doesn't have any replay value unless you want to revisit the exact same experience months or years down the road.

2. I ran into a few bugs in my short time with the game (version 1.01). Most of these were small graphical glitches that almost added to the surreal experience, but one actually prevented me from progressing. I spent twenty minutes or so trying to figure out how I was supposed to move forward before finally looking it up and seeing that I had encountered a bug. There is an in-game option to go to the last checkpoint, which I was able to use to fix this while only replaying about three minutes of the game, so it wasn't too bad, but the game is still in an early stage where you might hit a problem now and again.

3. I've seen at least one person in the forum complain that this brought up bad memories from their childhood. Presumably the subject matter advertised for the game should be enough to let you know if this will be a problem. It's a horror game where you play as a two year old, so keep that in mind if you have childhood trauma that could resurface.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep is a prime example of why horror is my favorite video game genre. The story is great, the monster encounters are exciting, unbearably tense, and are actually challenging unlike Amnesia The Dark Descent. Above all, Among the Sleep is incredibly creative and, despite its dark atmosphere, is very sentimental and succeeds in making the player feel like a little kid again.


PROLOGUE DLC REVIEW:

Among the Sleep comes with free DLC, which is a prologue which adds about an hour of gameplay mean to be played after the main campaign. Prologue is a skillfully designed addition to Among the Sleep and makes itself stand out from the campaign in several ways:

- A chilling winter atmosphere, which is refreshingly different
- Improved puzzles which require more thought to solve than what was seen in the campaign
- Thoroughly creepy dolls to collect

Prologue also expands upon the campaign's story, although since it's a prequel there is sadly no Teddy to keep you company. Prologue is actually very similar to Penumbra: Requiem, a mission pack/sequel to Penumbra: Black Plague. In Requiem there are no monsters to encounter, only environmental hazards and puzzles to solve. Prologue's only fault is that is pointlessly throws in a new monster which is a complete joke and takes the player out of their immersion. Considering that is all Prologue does wrong and the many other things it does right, it is a great bit of free DLC. Give it a go if you've played the campaign.

reviewText:
On one hand, the game is very atmospheric, the voice acting is excellent and the graphics are decent. On the other hand, the gameplay is exceptionally aggrevating, with the most egrecious parts involving hunting for pixels in the middle of dark areas.

Most game designers make their plot-relavent objects glow to provide some sense of guidance in order to prevent frusteration, and I found myself very frusterated through most of this game, and doubly so that the designers decided to make it so that your character was too young to walk properly so when you're attempting to locate said plot objects you have to constantly pick yourself up off the ground every ten feet or so, which breaks up the pacing terribly.

Its a real shame in a way, because Among the sleep does a lot of things right, and its clear the designers really put a lot of effort into the concept, but I can't in good concious recommend this, especially when Papo and Yo did the same idea much better.

Also, if you're prone to motion sickness keep in mind the characters head bobs like a duck.

reviewText:
Heres my video review version.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BOslDzCFl6U&index=5&list=PL5R7SNz81XUXF9-drfrHUqV7c75KYGyy6

Intro
Among The Sleep is a first person horror adventure Indie game developed and published by Krillbite Studios for PC, MAC, Linux and PS4.

Krillbite Studios is a Norwegian games Developer who has received over $300,000 Euro or ($500,000 USD) in total donations from The Norwegian Film Institute and from crowd funding..

Was their money well spent..


Story
In this adventure you play as a 2 year old child on his birthday, when a stranger knocks on the door‚Ä¶ to give you a present. the identity of this person is hidden from the player.

Shortly after this event your mum decides its time for you to play with your new gift, the teddy bear, so she takes you upstairs.

While going upstairs, the game is quick to kick in the creepy factor by making a wall of darkness follow you as the developer overlays there intro into this section.

I won‚Äôt tell you anything else beyond this point as it will ruin it for you.

Although I wouldn‚Äôt call Among the Sleep a horror game but it is still incredibly creepy and presents horror in a new light, more on that shortly.

This is essentially the prologue and basic knowledge about Among The Sleep, but it doesn‚Äôt really give you to much because I don‚Äôt want to give the story away. Any more story elements I lay out for you will completely destroy the story for you.


Gameplay
The gameplay consists of basic aspects such as crawling, running, object throwing and simple puzzles.

The walking animation is by far the best thing in this game :)

All jokes aside, the gameplay is simple yet fun and this is probably one of the first horror games with a defenceless protagonist that actually makes sense‚Ä¶.


Graphics
The visuals in Among the Sleep were impressive for an indie game running on the Unity engine, unlike most Unity based games there wasn‚Äôt any motion blur that was over powering me while I played, this feature can get quite annoying so Im glad they opted out of that idea.

There was one instance in the game were an object I needed to collect for progression didn‚Äôt actually fall down after hitting it sooo in order to continue I had to use a no clip console command to get it‚Ä¶

Later the game crashed and luckily they had a checkpoint before as when the game reloaded I was able to collect the object correctly.

Other than a few bugs here and there the game looked amazing and it really did feel like I was actually in this house, which for me made the experience that much more enjoyable.


Sound Design
The sound design in this game played an extremely important part, with ambient sound alone adding yet another layer of creepy to the environment which helped pull off a horror type experience.

Some sounds that would appear to be scare sounds, weren‚Äôt scary at all but seemed placed there to keep you on your toes which I thought was a neat inclusion.

Rather than trying to scare you constantly throughout the game, Krillbite decided to ease you into scares which if you havnt seen part 5 of my playthrough I would strongly recommend you go watch that, to get a real understanding as to what I am referring to.

P.S. I nearly flew out of my chair

Verdict
Although there was a decent amount objects clipping through walls here and there‚Ä¶ the core game didn‚Äôt get effected by this and the creepiness of this game grasped me in and made me want to understand what was going on in this world.

Which for a horror game is a great step up from the rest‚Ä¶ and well you‚Äôre a 2 year old with a talking teddy what more can you ask for.

Bugs and issues aside, Among the Sleep was a solid indie game developed by Krillbite Studios and seeing as this is their first game‚Ä¶ they didn‚Äôt do a whole lot wrong.

That is why Among the Sleep gets an 8/10.

reviewText: I've always been a fan of indie games, particularly indie horror games. I went into Among the Sleep with minimal information, I just saw that you played as a infant, and I knew I had to have it. The adventure that followed starting from 12 to around 3 in the morning some might say was shortlived, however I loved every bit of it. The atmosphere, symbolism, and thought that this game provokes stemming from the question of what is real and what is imagination from the point of a two year old was comparable in complexity to the ending of Bioshock Infinite. I also find it comparable to movies such as American Psycho and Donnie Darko in the same way. Not everyone will have the same interpretation, although I have heard very good ones in the forums. If you expect from this game cheap jumps scares or award winning graphics or action, look somewhere else. This game is more of an allegory within a haunting art form, and I will fondly remember those nearly three hours I spent on this game, as  I will also remember what I took away.

reviewText:
Honestly I've really really enjoyed this game. I'll start off by saying if you're a big fan of jumpscare horrors than this game IS NOT for you. The game uses creepy atmospheres and frightening visuals to scare you. If you're looking for a long game, this is also NOT for you. The game itself is about 3-4 hours long (depending on how cautiously you play).

I do feel that there is some wasted opportunity here to be honest. The game places you in the role of a sweet, care-free baby that is plunged into a dark twisted world. The game's story may appear loose and almost non-existent at parts but there is a sudden realisation during the game of everything that has been going on, and everything will definitely make sense once you reach the end of the game. The ending really makes the game in my opinion.

I played the game feeling slightly on edge the whole time, having not figured out the game's style yet. I think the fact it is so short almost helps it. You never get a chance to figure out how this game is going to scare you until you've already finished it.

Overall a fun and creepy game, but shouldn't really be classed as a 'horror' in the traditional sense, but it will give you a scare here and there.

I like Among the Sleep, and though I wish I could say that I ‚Äòlove‚Äô Among the Sleep, I just can‚Äôt; not with its overly simplified puzzles and super short length. reviewText: Among the Sleep instantly grabbed my attention when it was first announced due to its interesting premise and an unlikely protagonist: an infant. The survival horror genre excels at making players feel uncomfortable due to an increased sense of vulnerability the fact that you play as a toddler is Among the Sleep's most unusual characteristic, and also one of its best. This isn't just a first-person game in which the camera is lower to the ground than it would be if you were playing as an adult. When you walk, your steps feel unsteady; you can get around more quickly by crawling, but walking has its advantages. On foot, you can drag objects around, and you can open drawers, which you often need to clamber up onto in order to reach doorknobs or get to higher areas. By making you interact with the world in this teetering way from this perspective, Among the Sleep makes the fact that you play as a toddler not just a narrative conceit, but an integral part of your experience.

reviewText:
Score: 8/10
Price/Value: $10
Time: 2 hours

*Spoilers Ahead*

Among the Sleep turned out to be a wonderful surprise. You play as a wee two year old toddler navigating a world which appears nightmarish to your infant eyes. Many people will be reminded immediately of the Penumbra series when it comes to world interaction (chests, drawers, opening doors, object manipulation).

Artistically, this game is lovely to look at. Coats, boots and everyday objects are made out to be creatures in the dark or stylized into the creatures themselves. The baby's room is well done and being able to look down and see your tiny self fidgeting like a child might actually do in reality is a neat little thing to include. The mother looks fantastic and the lighting sets the mood for the rather dark and sad story they are telling.

This is where we get into spoilers. The gist of the story is that the creatures from your nightmares are actually your mother and, from what I am guessing, either your father or some form of social services worker. As you might have guessed from that last sentence, your mother is losing you. The symbolism that is put forth in the child's drawings scattered around the level was an interesting inclusion to go along with the theme of child abuse, alcoholism and misunderstanding that children have when these things happen really sealed this up into a gem.

Seeing your mother in the floor of the kitchen, your bear in one hand and wine glass in the other weeping left me cold inside at the end. Realising that the witch in the well from your children's story is your mother and her alcoholism struck a chord and is relatable I'm sure to many people growing up from all walks of life.

This is easily a gem and worth it at any price.
Not really a horror title as I thought it might be more-so, but actually something much deeper and more meaningful.

reviewText:
[Updated with a positive review now I can actually finish the game]

I feel I can now recommend this game. Whilst it's a little clunky and can be beaten in just a couple of hours, it more than makes up for that by sheer force of concept.

If the idea has been tried before then I haven't seen it. A horror game told from the point of view of a 2-year old. Genius! They find things scary that we don't, and so you end up in a world which heavily blurs the line between reality and imagination. Ever thought innocent objects made scary shadows in the middle of the night? Well, here they do!

The level design is very well crafted and you rarely find yourself wandering round in circles looking for something to do. It's a little linear in places, but you feel more like you're being guided in the right direction rather than simply being on rails.

However, it's taken six months since release for me to be able to actually play the game as it's been absolutely infested with bugs. One showstopping glitch made it impossible for me to even complete the first chapter, hence the negative review I originally posted here. I still have minor bugs including achievements not working, but at least the game is now completable for me. If it works for you, it's a fascinating original game. Try the demo first to see if it works for you. As one of the original Kickstarter backers it's made me wary about pledging towards the developer's next project though...

reviewText:
This game caught my attention a while ago when it was still on Kickstarter. Since I love the promise of horror games like this, and because I play most games for the story anyway, of course I had to play this one.

After reading several of the reviews about how short the game is, how scary it is, and how interesting the storyline is, I have to say that after playing, I found that none of those things were true.

‚Ä¶Okay okay, so I lied. Yeah, it was scary. I was afraid. It doesn‚Äôt take much anymore. I used to be tougher‚Ä¶ *ahem* But the thing many reviewers seemed to be saying was how vulnerable they felt while playing as a young child without a weapon, how they couldn‚Äôt move very fast, etc. Actually, instead of making me feel vulnerable, this aspect made me feel MORE secure. First, I‚Äôm a BABY, so I didn‚Äôt imagine I had bloody death to fear. Who is going to make a game like that? Second, I‚Äôm tiny! Who can even see me?? I‚Äôm crawling around and hiding under things! And yes, I spent most of the game doing this. I‚Äôm pretty sure that most of the time, I was not even hiding from anything at all. Which brings me to my second untruth.

The game is short. Yes, it‚Äôs pretty simple, but the thing (for me) was that I kept hiding and just sitting there going ‚Äòwhat was that??‚Äô and thinking I needed to run and hide in the cabinet at every little sound, that I actually managed to get 10+ hours out of it. ‚Ä¶Okay so maybe that‚Äôs not an accomplishment. Like I said, I spent a lot of time hiding from a monster that I‚Äôm pretty sure wasn‚Äôt even around when I thought it might be, but that was part of what made the game scary. I didn‚Äôt exactly know what was after me for a long time, and I spent quite a while just hiding out and praying that nothing would jump out at me. I was doing pretty well until the first time I had an ‚Äòit‚Äôs right behind me!‚Äô experience, which gave me trust issues with the game that I couldn‚Äôt quite get over. Moving on.

The storyline‚Ä¶ I thought I‚Äôd get to be clever and say that I had the story figured out within the first 5 minutes. (Not the whole story, but the story behind the story‚Ä¶story. Yeah.) But as the game went on, and after I had gotten my first close encounter with the monster, I had to change my theory, but only slightly. I was pretty close, and really, the story isn‚Äôt complicated at all. If you pay attention to the clues, you can figure it out.

So, overall, I say that the game is worth experiencing ‚Äì maybe even more in the way it was meant to be played, in 3D. I bought it during the summer sale for 15% off, but honestly, like others, I‚Äôm not sure it was really worth what I paid. So, yeah, it was fun, scary, and if you‚Äôre a fan of horror games check it out, but don‚Äôt expect anything profound.

reviewText:
ATTENTION:  IF YOUR ON THE FENCE ABOUT THIS GAME READ THIS!!!

I don't really know what to rate this game.  Like... I loved the game.  But it feels unfinished in a few places.  I won't give away any plot but I will say a few things I find important.

first off the pros.  This game does a fantastic job of setting up an atmosphere.  I honestly got extremely emersed in the world by the end of the game and at a few moments I felt like my bones were about to jump right out of my skin.  The story may seem dull at first, but the ending will leave you wanting to go through the game again for sure to pick up on things you might have missed.  Scary parts are pretty scary and a couple of jump moments really make the game a fantastic experience.

Now the cons.  first off, the game is way too short.  I mean I literally beat the whole thing in around 2 hours.  Part of this is because the puzzles are very simple and don't require a lot of thought.  It felt very from point A to point B and while this normally works for horror games, I didn't feel like anything was stopping me from plowing on ahead.  this is because the game takes its time with setting up the horror moments.  Similar to Amnesia the game takes about an hour or so to actually get to the meat and potatoes.  This works for amnesia because the game is long and takes time.  However I didn't first encounter anything scary until I was 70% through the game. (other than one moment) and that sort of ticked me off.

So over all I think this game is fantastic.  However at $19.99 that is robbery.  the game is worth about $5-$8.  So many things  could have been improved on including more lore and more reason to explore.  The only things you find are drawings which you can't even collect, just look at as you pass.  Overall if you love horror games and appreciate a good story with a fantastic plot twist this game is a must.  I also feel it's perfect for an intro horror game as the game isn't too long and isn't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• your pants scary.  Of course get it at the right price.

reviewText: 10/10 Artworks looks stunning, presentation is excellent, perfect length for a game like this. Exceeded expectations, I love that they don't spell anything out for you, figuring out the story for yourself is part of it. The gameplay is simple and perfect. Most noticably, the game isn't arduous and long, it can be completed in 3-4 hours, which is perfect because even in horror games like amnesia or outlast, I find that after I've been playing it for too long, or if I have to return to it later in order to complete it, it drops me out of the experience and by the end of the game I'm sprinting with wreckless abandon and my sense of immersion drops. Not to mention there aren't any extended puzzles or stealth sequences that halt your progression. Additionally I'd like to point out that this isn't exactly a horror game as much as it is a scary psychological adventure, and it absolutely nails it.

reviewText:
Among the Sleep. Holy Russel Crowe. I cannot stop the praise shooting from my mouth. I Let's Played this for my channel, and you can find the footage in it's entirety here. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLk69TxLkva1YHrLxJe6Ho2qmwFrmycnpK

The premise of Among the Sleep is you are a two year old toddler, trying to find your mommy in what has become a living, breathing nightmare. While the game never stops reminding you of that one simple goal, it doesn't wave it around in your face like others do; it is the main objective of the smaller storyline but you are not constantly bombarded with it enough to make you feel uncomfortable.

The cast of characters is small, featuring only three main characters (You the Toddler, Teddy, and your Mom). The voice acting, however, is marvelously done. For the small cast and the small script, the voicework imbeds you in the game. For that matter, the entire game's soundscape is gorgeous from the lullaby-like background music to the sometimes spine-vibrating sound effects. Everything makes you feel as if you truly exist in this world, alone.

The level design is beautiful, taking items one would see laying around a household and twisting them into mighty structures; a park becomes a shadow-cast forest, a set of drawers is an insurmountable mountain, closets are deep caverns where the darkness goes to cling... While there are only four main level segments in the game, they are sprawling, each taking thirty minutes to traverse through in their entirety and every corner beautifully defined and articulated.

The gameplay itself is simple, you control a toddler. You can crawl, pickup objects, walk, run, and hug your teddy. While very simple, you'll be using all of this to ford a nightmarish take on reality, collecting and interacting with objects, engaging in some platforming, and navigating very dark areas. Occasionally you'll come face to face with a monster, which will scare you, making it difficult to see and navigate, as well as filling your ears with the game's version of the traditional, 'jump scare noise.' In darker segements, you can hug your friend, Teddy, to generate some light for you to navigate. While this makes things easier to do, in many cases you won't ever need to hug teddy as you can navigate in the dim lighting.

The game is as short as it really needs to be, only clocking in at about two hours. The storyline isn't overtly complex, so instead of forcing more unessecary content out of it, the devs made this game short and (not so) sweet when it came to the story itself. While many people may not realize it until the end, this game is based around one very pevelent social issue we face today, and it will shock you to your core when you reach the game's finale.

Overall, Among the Sleep is a great game. It's short, but sweet, and while it does have little replay value, I'd love to play it again with a loved one. Every production point of the game is absolutely beautiful, but sadly it is pitifully short. If you're not convinced, wait for the price to drop by a few dollars in a sale, then pick it up. You will not regret it.

reviewText:
In Among the Sleep, by Krillbite Studio, you will take on the role of a 2 year old child who just had his birthday. You are eating cake in the arms of your mom when there is a knock at the door. This is followed by an argument, and then your mom coming back in with a present. You then fast forward to around bedtime/nap time, I'm not really sure which. It is then that the game takes on a nightmarish overlay.

The visual look of this game felt like it fit with the character being a 2 year old. I'm not saying that it was rainbows and puppies, but there were those softer colors, even when everything was dark. The levels of this game were beyond creepy, especially for me because I have an almost 2 year old, so I could see myself in his shoes. There is a slight terror to knowing that something bad could happen right out of the corner of your eye. The levels span from a deserted play ground, a library in a forest, small sections of your house, and more. There are villains that creep around as well. All I have to say is you are going to need to hide from them, or you will suffer a restart of the section you are in. I also really enjoyed the companion, the teddy bear that helped me along. All I had to do was hug it and he would produce a little bit of light that would help me see through the darkness.

The sounds in this game are extremely creepy. Once again it was doubley so because I have a young son, and hearing those noises creep around in a dark area would scare the pants off me at that age. I also think the voice acting in this game was spot on. I could see the roles of the mother and the teddy bear in the voices given.

The controls of the game are your usual configuration with WASD, shift to run, ctrl to crawl or get up, space to climb, and the mouse to control the camera and interact with objects.

Though this game wasn't as long as I would have hoped, it definitely had enough there to keep me on my toes, and hoping that nothing was going to get me around the next corner. There is just something about this game that awakened long gone fears of my childhood, and the fear of what is in the dark. In this respect the developers did a great job. To be honest I can't really think of anything I found clunky or missing from this game. I will tell you this, the twist is a hell of one, and I'm not going to tell you what it is because you need to play this game to find out, but when the game ends everything kind of makes better sense.

There were definitely puzzle aspects to this game, most of the time it was moving objects so that you could get to a different location, but there were a couple of times where the developers threw in a mechanism just for a small section of the game that changed things up a little. A couple examples of this would be throwing objects to knock something off a shelf, or collecting a specific type of object so that you could weigh down the end of something so you could get to the other side. I'm not saying that this was a bad thing, but I would have liked to see a little bit more of these mechanics, to do them once and then seeming to throw them away made me feel like they were afterthoughts in the game creation process.

So lets get down to the part that most of you want to know, and that is should you play this game. The answer is yes, you should play this game, and you should play it in the dark, at night, and pray that no one sneaks up behind you while you are playing. This game gets an 8.9 out of 10.

reviewText:
I remember when I first heard about this Kickstarter for a horror game from the perspective of a toddler, and I was terrified already. They didn't have to promise me any more than that, I was sold.

Among the Sleep certainly delivers on that particular promise. It doesn't go much above and beyond, but it really didn't have to. It was suitably scary, with good flow and an appropriate arc. The minor platforming and puzzles were rarely challenging, but they helped a lot with the pacing of the game, and appropriately added to the tension or distracted from it. There really isn't anything I can complain about in the game.

My biggest issue with it was how short it was; it took me just over 2.5 hours to complete, and I was thoroughly looking through every room because I wanted to get all of the achievements in one playthrough. They are planning on coming out with a free DLC, but there is no word yet on what that will be about or how long it will be.

Because of the length of the game, I would recommend spending $10 on this game at the maximum. Unless the DLC absolutely blows me away, I wouldn't expect that verdict to change.

reviewText:
Pros: Gorgeous art design.  Creepy sound design.  Some really good scares.  Playing as a 2 year old isn't a gimmick, it's well integrated into the story, map design, and controls.  It's really cool analyzing what you see from the kid's perspective.

Cons: I don't usually complain about game length if the experience feels complete (I thought Dear Esther was worth the price for example) but this game clocked in at around 3 hours and felt brief, like it needed one more level to ramp up the insanity before the epilogue.  Some major bugs that affected rendering or caused the game to glitch out requiring me to load a checkpoint.  Doesn't stray from the linear, modern explore, hide, collect horror formula.  Not a lot of replay value, and the story isn't as thought provoking as other games like 'Machine for Pigs' in a way that would make up for that.

Verdict: I don't regret paying full price for the experience, since the art and sound are truly marvelous, but for most people I'd reccommend waiting for a patch and a sale.  If you like what you see in the trailer, that's the game you're getting.  But it feels brief, lacks some polish, and is definitely more style than substance.

reviewText:
3/5
Good Music and environment, surreal and immersive, but too brief, overpriced, and simplistic.
Literally Amnesia for babies

A lot of people have said the same things about this game already, so this is pretty much rehashing the public opinion. Nevertheless, I enjoyed the game. It was immersive, and had the child-like whimsy I'd expect, with a growing sense of dread and fear always lurking in the background. Even in the opening credits, when the black smoke crawls across the floor, or when the mother looks away and leaves you alone, and you start to panic in your chair, little moments like that helped seal the deal for me.
The settings were interesting, pleasantly surreal and vibrant, even when they are dimly lit. However, most of the objects and things you come across are random and have no significance, aside from the scrawled drawings all over. The puzzles were fairly simple, which allows you to focus a bit more on the story. Or it would, if the story was much more than explore the place until you solve the puzzle...

The monsters shocked me at first, and even throughout the first encounters I was paralyzed in my hiding spot. However, after a while when I realized they were easily avoided I had little issue and little to fear.
At one point I even got caught, which sends you back to a checkpoint, and instantly reduces the terror they represent when they become little more than a funny looking obstacle.

The ending wasn't a twist or a surprise if you pay attention at all to any of the sketchy stick figures, and the bottles littering the place. I was hoping for something a bit darker, but perhaps it's appropriate to have it be something so simple yet devastating... Poignant, but not very exciting.

I think I enjoyed the playground level the best...

Big issue is it's so brief for it's pricetag. $19.99 for something you're done with in a couple hours, with nothing in the way of replay value.  If the price were halved, it would be more reasonable, and more fitting for its content.

reviewText: This was such an amazing and satisfying game.  It was short but I definitely reccommend it.  It was creepy in a very realistic kind of way, which usually isn't covered so perfectly in horror games.  What first drew me was the fact that it was in the perspective of a 2 year old, which hits close to home with me as I used to have really bad nightmares when I was younger.  It's nostalgic in a weird kind of way.  If you're interested in games like Outlast or Amnesia, this is very similar but unique in its own amazing and artistic way.  You are helpless to fight back against the monster that chases you around, similar to those two games, and you also can alert the monster to you by causing disturbances around the area.  The thing that polishes it off is that, as a 2 year old, you are going through stages when reality and imagination merge together and you are still learning to distinguish between the two, which means that vivid dreams are something that would seem more realistic to a 2 year old than an adult.  It allows more flexibility in their creativity and they take advantage of that tenfold.  UNLIKE Amnesia and Outlast, these are dream worlds and irrational fears that many people shared when they were younger which in contrast makes it more terrifying and beautiful.  Definitely support these games, seriously, Krillbite is simply awesome in their abilities.
